chunks.original_text: 占神月空剧乳妇庐法第八 常以璇玑加三五孟，谓寅午戌之月则加寅，申子辰月加申，巳酉丑加巳，亥卯未加亥。 天罡下为天候，太一下为轩辕，小吉下为招摇，从魁下为月杀，河魁下为雷公，登明下为成池，神后下为丰隆。 又为昊时时刑者，寅刑、已巳刑、申申刑，寅无恩之刑也。 丑刑、戌戌刑、未未刑，丑逆刑也。 子刑、卯卯刑、子互相刑也。 孟月以功曹，仲月以神后，季月以魁临月建，视天上丙壬。 丙壬所临地下，皆空吉可居也。 皆避雷公、招摇、轩辕、成池、具时、丰隆、天候、时刑矣。 占知臣吏心善恶法第九 以问时事，占之一云：天罡加月建为重阳，天魁加太岁为重阴。 罡临太岁为阳覆阴，臣欺君。 魁加月建为阴覆阳，君欺臣也日辰上神，阴得吉。 神将有王相气、休气，上下相生，与日辰上神不相克，则臣下忠孝，常怀爱上敬教。 日辰上阴神得凶，将有王相气、休气，下贱其上。 又今日之辰，自贼其日及辰，阴上日神贼上神，此臣下不忠顺，奸猾难折勒骄，常有篡 弒之心也。 假令阴上神登明天空，贪污慢欺朱雀，巧言令色，天罡勾陈，持上罪过，魁居白兽，欲为大乱。 假令九月丙午日中时，占臣下心意何如？ 功曹临丙，丙上遇前三之将也。 太冲临午，午上得前四之将也。 功曹阴上神得登明，将得天一。 天一居日之阴神太冲，上神得神后，将为腾蛇。 腾蛇辰上，辰上阴神为发用也。 皆上下相生自和，遥生日辰上阳神，功曹太冲，此为臣下忠孝，安上爱下也。 此亦是雨神克日，以日比为用。 故用神后子，取有两子之比，主忧从外来之事也。 假令六月壬辰日，日入时，胜先临酉，酉上遇后一之也，以此酉时天一乘太冲。 传送为临，壬日上阳神也，大吉。 为临辰，辰上阳神也，传送阴上神，得太一日之阴神，太一发用也。 上克下。 又遥贼日上神大吉为神之阳其阴上见传送也得魁，魁为凶神。 辰之阴上神后五之将也。 今日之辰复贼日，谓辰土贼壬水。 此为臣子不忠孝，谋欲乱君，以钱财之事，他效此。 占人君欲拜署五官法第十 记吏当谒时，无令所谒之官。 伤君年上神到王相时，为君忧患。 以君年上神，将为所忧形状，当谒水官曹吏； 无令火神临君年，谒木官曹吏； 无令土神临君年，谒金官曹吏； 无令木神临君年。 假令君年立巳，当谒金官曹吏。 时功曹临巳，将为朱雀，为伤君年上神。 金克木故也。 朱雀告言口舌事也。 利秋金王时，必为所言於上府，皆效之功曹庭掾，为土官曹库吏，为金官狱曹、贼曹、仓部曹； 皆为水官卧曹，为木官户曹，为火官外部吏； 及内不属五曹者，皆属功曹，为土官。 占诸君吏吉凶法第十一 将及小吏，始入官临政视事时，慎无令人年上神。 贼初拜除； 日又无令所出门上神贼人年上神。 文官欲得青龙，武官欲得太常，与日辰相生，不欲相刑克。 神枢云：欲入文官、武官，必今日辰阴阳中，及用传中有青龙、太常者，吉也。 假令人年立丑，以甲乙日拜官署事，始到官视事时，始从魁临丑。 此谓人年上神贼初拜除日也。 假令人年立亥，小吉临之，而南之午地视事时，功曹临午。 此所出门上神贼人年上神也。 文官视事，青龙在胜先。 此谓与日相生，必迁日辰阴阳传中，宜视其神所言之。

「占神月空剧乳妇庐法第八
When the *Xuan-Ji* (璇玑) is combined with the Three Five Mends (三五孟), the taboos for nursing mothers are as follows:
If the month’s governing hour is *Yin-Wei* (寅午戌), add *Yin* (寅);
If it is *Shen-Zi* (申子辰), add *Shen* (申);
If it is *Wei-You-Chou* (巳酉丑), add *Wei* (巳);
If it is *Hai-Mao-Wu* (亥卯未), add *Hai* (亥).

The *Tian-Gang* (天罡) corresponds to *Tian-Hou* (天侯),
The *Tai-Yi* (太一) corresponds to *Xuan-Yuan* (轩辕),
The *Xiao-Ji* (小吉) corresponds to *Zhao-Yao* (招摇),
The *Cong-Kui* (从魁) corresponds to *Yue-Yin* (月饮),
The *He-Kui* (河魁) corresponds to *Lei-Gong* (雷公),
The *Deng-Ming* (登明) corresponds to *Cheng-Chi* (成池),
And the *Shen-Hou* (神后) corresponds to *Feng-Long* (丰隆).

The *Hao-Shi* (昊时) is also the *Shi-Xing* (时刑):
*Yin* (寅) is *En-Xing* (恩刑, the "Graceful Penalty"),
*Wei* (巳) is *Wei-Wei-Xing* (巳巳刑, the "Wei Penalty"),
*Shen* (申) is *Shen-Shen-Xing* (申申刑, the "Shen Penalty").

*Chou* (丑) is *Ni-Xing* (逆刑, the "Inverted Penalty"),
*Xu* (戌) is *Xu-Xu-Xing* (戌戌刑, the "Xu Penalty"),
*Wu* (未) is *Wu-Wu-Xing* (未未刑, the "Wu Penalty").

*Zi* (子) is *Hu-Xing* (互刑, the "Reciprocal Penalty"),
*Mao* (卯) is *Mao-Mao-Xing* (卯卯刑, the "Mao Penalty").

For the first month, use the *Gong-Cao* (功曹);
For the second month, use the *Shen-Hou* (神后);
For the third month, use the *Kui* (魁).
The month’s governing hour is determined by the *Tian-Shang* (天上) *Bing-Ren* (丙壬).
Wherever *Bing-Ren* (丙壬) descends upon the earth,
those places are all *Kong-Ji* (空吉, "Empty Auspiciousness") and may be occupied.

All must avoid the *Lei-Gong* (雷公), *Zhao-Yao* (招摇), *Xuan-Yuan* (轩辕), *Cheng-Chi* (成池), *Ju-Shi* (具时), *Feng-Long* (丰隆), *Tian-Hou* (天侯), and *Shi-Xing* (时刑).

占知臣吏心善恶法第九
To determine the benevolence or malevolence of officials and ministers:
When inquiring about affairs of the time,
the method is as follows:
If *Tian-Gang* (天罡) is combined with the month’s governing hour, it is *Chong-Yang* (重阳, "Double Yang");
If *Tian-Kui* (天魁) is combined with the *Tai-Sui* (太岁), it is *Chong-Yin* (重阴, "Double Yin").

If *Tian-Gang* (天罡) descends upon the *Tai-Sui* (太岁), it is *Yang-Fu-Yin* (阳覆阴, "Yang Over Yin"),
indicating that ministers deceive their superiors.

If *Tian-Kui* (天魁) is combined with the month’s governing hour, it is *Yin-Fu-Yang* (阴覆阳, "Yin Over Yang"),
indicating that superiors deceive their ministers.

When the *Shen* (神) is upon the day’s hour,
if the Yin receives *Ji* (吉, auspiciousness),
and the *Shen* (神) has *Wang-Xiang-Qi* (王相气, "Royal Ministerial Qi") or *Xiu-Qi* (休气, "Restorative Qi"),
with the upper and lower harmoniously generating,
and the day’s hour’s Yang *Shen* (神) does not clash with it,
then the ministers are loyal and filial,
constantly cherishing their superiors and respecting their teachings.

If the day’s hour’s Yin *Shen* (神) receives *Xiang* (凶, inauspiciousness),
and the *Shen* (神) has *Wang-Xiang-Qi* (王相气) or *Xiu-Qi* (休气),
then the ministers disrespect their superiors.

Furthermore, if the day’s hour itself harms its own governing hour,
and the Yin *Shen* (神) above the day’s hour harms the *Shen* (神) above,
this indicates that ministers are not loyal and obedient,
deceitful and difficult to discipline,
ever harboring treasonous and regicidal intentions.

Suppose the Yin *Shen* (神) above ascends to *Deng-Ming* (登明) in Heaven,
coveting and oppressing the *Zhu-Que* (朱雀),
using flattery and deceitful words,
while *Tian-Gang* (天罡) is *Gou-Chen* (勾陈),
holding the superiors accountable for their crimes.
If *Kui* (魁) resides in the *Bai-Shou* (白兽),
it will cause great chaos.

Suppose in the ninth month on a *Bing-Wu* (丙午) day at midday,
how should one interpret the ministers’ intentions?
*Gong-Cao* (功曹) descends upon *Bing* (丙),
and the *Bing* (丙) hour receives the *Shen* (神) of the first three months.
*Tai-Chong* (太冲) descends upon *Wu* (午),
and the *Wu* (午) hour receives the *Shen* (神) of the first four months.
If *Gong-Cao* (功曹) receives the Yin *Shen* (神) of *Deng-Ming* (登明),
it will become the *Tian-Yi* (天一, "Heavenly Unity").
*Tian-Yi* (天一) resides in the Yin *Shen* (神) of the day’s hour *Tai-Chong* (太冲),
and the *Shen* (神) above receives *Shen-Hou* (神后),
becoming the *Teng-She* (腾蛇, "Soaring Serpent").
The hour of *Teng-She* (腾蛇) is upon the hour of *Chen* (辰),
and the Yin *Shen* (神) of *Chen* (辰) is the *Fa-Yong* (发用, "Manifestation").

All upper and lower qi harmoniously generate and align,
while the Yang *Shen* (神) of the day’s hour is upon *Gong-Cao* (功曹) and *Tai-Chong* (太冲).
This indicates that ministers are loyal and filial,
peaceful and loving toward their superiors.

This is also the case when the *Yu-Shen* (雨神, "Rain God") subdues the day,
as the day’s hour corresponds to its use.
Hence, the *Shen-Hou* (神后) is upon *Zi* (子),
and the *Zi* (子) hour has two auspicious comparisons,
indicating worries arising from external matters.

Suppose in the sixth month on a *Ren-Chen* (壬辰) day,
when the sun sets and enters the hour,
*Sheng-Xian* (胜先) descends upon *You* (酉),
and the *You* (酉) hour receives the *Shen* (神) of the last month,
thus the *Tian-Yi* (天一) rides upon *Tai-Chong* (太冲).

*Chuan-Song* (传送) is the governing hour,
and the Yang *Shen* (神) of the *Ren* (壬) day is auspicious.
*Chuan-Song* (传送) descends upon *Chen* (辰),
and the Yang *Shen* (神) of the *Chen* (辰) hour is the governing hour.
The Yin *Shen* (神) of *Chuan-Song* (传送) receives the Yin *Shen* (神) of *Tai-Yi* (太一),
which is the *Fa-Yong* (发用, "Manifestation").

The upper qi subdues the lower.
Furthermore, if the Yang *Shen* (神) of the day’s hour is auspicious,
and the *Shen* (神) is upon *Chuan-Song* (传送),
then the Yin *Shen* (神) above sees the *Chuan-Song* (传送),
which is the *Kui* (魁), the inauspicious god.
The Yin *Shen* (神) of the *Chen* (辰) hour is the *Shen* (神) of the fifth month.
The hour of this day again harms the hour of the day,
meaning the *Chen* (辰) earth harms the *Ren* (壬) water.
This indicates that ministers are not loyal and filial,
plotting to overthrow their superiors,
often involving matters of money and wealth.
Other cases follow this pattern.

占人君欲拜署五官法第十
When a ruler intends to appoint officials:
At the time of the official’s appointment,
ensure that the governing hour of the official’s office is not harmed.
If the *Shen* (神) of the ruler’s year descends upon the *Wang-Xiang* (王相) hour,
it will bring worries and troubles to the ruler.
The *Shen* (神) of the ruler’s year forms the appearance of the concern,
and the official should be appointed to a water office;
Do not allow the Fire *Shen* (神) to descend upon the ruler’s year,
and appoint the official to a wood office;
Do not allow the Earth *Shen* (神) to descend upon the ruler’s year,
and appoint the official to a metal office;
Do not allow the Wood *Shen* (神) to descend upon the ruler’s year.

Suppose the ruler’s year is *Wei* (巳),
and the official is to be appointed to a metal office.
At this time, *Gong-Cao* (功曹) descends upon *Wei* (巳),
becoming the *Zhu-Que* (朱雀),
harming the *Shen* (神) of the ruler’s year.
Metal subdues Wood, hence the harm.
*Zhu-Que* (朱雀) indicates matters of speech and litigation.
It is advantageous to appoint in the autumn when Metal is in power,
as the official’s words will be heard in the higher echelons.
All cases follow this pattern.

*Gong-Cao* (功曹) officials include:
*Ting-Yan* (庭掾) for Earth offices,
*Kou-Li* (库吏) for *Gong-Cao* (功曹) Earth offices,
*Jing-Cao* (狱曹), *Zei-Cao* (贼曹), and *Cang-Bu-Cao* (仓部曹) for Metal offices;
All are also for Water offices,
*Hu-Cao* (户曹) for Wood offices,
and *Wai-Bu-Li* (外部吏) for Fire offices.
Those not affiliated with the five offices are all under *Gong-Cao* (功曹),
serving as Earth officials.

占诸君吏吉凶法第十一
To determine the auspiciousness or inauspiciousness of all officials and ministers:
When the ruler and ministers begin their official duties,
be cautious that the *Shen* (神) of the ruler’s year does not harm the officials.
If the *Shen* (神) harms the officials upon their first appointment,
or if the *Shen* (神) of the hour where they exit harms the *Shen* (神) of the ruler’s year,
then for civil officials, seek *Qing-Long* (青龙, "Azure Dragon"),
and for military officials, seek *Tai-Chang* (太常, "Grand Minister").
The governing hour should harmonize with the day’s hour,
and avoid mutual harm or subjugation.

The *Shen-Shu* (神枢) states:
To enter civil or military offices,
the day’s hour must either be Yin-Yang balanced,
or the *Yong-Shen* (用神, "functional deity") must include *Qing-Long* (青龙) or *Tai-Chang* (太常) for auspiciousness.

Suppose the ruler’s year is *Chou* (丑),
and on *Jia-Yi* (甲乙) days, they are appointed to office and begin their duties.
If *Cong-Kui* (从魁) descends upon *Chou* (丑) at the start,
this indicates that the *Shen* (神) of the ruler’s year harms the officials on their first appointment.

Suppose the ruler’s year is *Hai* (亥),
and *Xiao-Ji* (小吉) descends upon it,
while in the southern *Wu* (午) land they begin their duties,
and *Gong-Cao* (功曹) descends upon *Wu* (午).
This indicates that the *Shen* (神) of the hour where they exit harms the *Shen* (神) of the ruler’s year.

For civil officials, *Qing-Long* (青龙) is upon *Sheng-Xian* (胜先).
This indicates that it harmonizes with the day’s hour,
and one must shift the day’s hour and Yin-Yang *Yong-Shen* (用神),
observing the governing hour’s statements.

chunks.original_text: 欲知迁官，离青龙、太常为月期，以青龙所临辰为时期。 假令从魁临未，而文官欲入官视事，胜先为青龙临辰，以甲柑生法迁增。 利日离青龙三辰为三岁辰，离青龙七辰为七月青龙。 所居之神主土，其日戌巳青龙加辰为时。 期后三岁七月戊已日辰时，迁太常效青龙。 月生青龙、太常，为迁在外； 青龙太常生日，迁在内。 内者，坐迁增秩。 即不备此法者，慎无令魁歪、剩蛇、白虎、玄武临日辰，人年立行恶加其墓，即不可用也。 甲乙墓在未，丙丁墓在戌，庚辛墓在丑，壬癸墓及戊己墓，并在辰。 神枢日凶期，以青龙太常所畏为忧期，以四时之气休老囚死为所坐轻重，他效此。 占诸吏吉凶迁否法第十二 以月将加时日辰，及人年上得吉； 神将上下相生，即大吉。 其神又有王相气时，加王相之乡，为得迁。 非此者，皆凶。 得休气，且免官； 退罢囚气，且系上下又相贼； 有罪死气凶恶神，传得吉神将有救，为忧外，日上神将王相吉，为迁。 年上神将王相吉，亦迁。 日年上神皆凶，辰上神虽善，为不迁。 日辰年皆吉，为迁不疑也。 欲知迁期，以魁离今日之辰为期。 假令今日之辰是寅，魁加午，为在向后五日，若五月，他效此。 金柜云：迁不迁问何官？ 谓问文武之官也。 说曰：日辰上皆有王相气，迁文官。 若阴上神有王相气，迁武官。 日辰及阴上上神俱相，重迁。 用神加孟仲，迁在内加季官迁在外。 占诸吏君安官舍欲知家内吉凶法第十三 日辰上之阴得吉神将，有王相气者吉。 休囚皆凶，次神将言其形状。 假令得天魁为白虎，主死丧； 玄武，言亡遗矣。 欲知衰吉是谁，以年上神言之，阳神为父，阴神为母。 神枢所谓：安不安以神士向，则是此之例也。 占诸吏安官否法第十四 日辰人年上得吉神将，休气上下相生者为安官。 其有王相气迁。 其神将凶有王相气，上下相生，亦安官。 上下相贼，不安官。 吉神凶将俱有气，又上下相贼者，弥不安也。 得传送，有行来事； 得朱雀，口舌、言讼事； 得玄武、亡遗、盗忧、疑事也。 光明符云：以月将加月建，行年上见休老之气者，免官。 神枢云：日辰阴阳俱囚休废者，当失职矣。 占君吏欲刑戮举事法第十五 人君及部吏欲得行刑，推问当事时，无令天一吉神将，及王相之气临今日之辰。 吉神者，谓功曹、胜光、传送、神后、大小吉也。 吉将者，谓天一、六合、青龙、太常、太阴、天后也。 皆不可使临今日之辰，与辰之阴。 又辰阴上之神，不可使克。 人年上神克人年上神，必还害身也。 假令人年立未，太冲临之今日之辰巳也。 大吉临巳，大吉。 阴在丑，从魁加丑，此为阴上之神克人年上神。 法行此事，吉神将及王相气临今日之辰，与辰之阴上神贼人年上神，谓从魁克太冲也。 殃及后嗣，害子孙，人年，谓人君及部吏之会也。 他效此。 占诸郡县有盗贼否法第十六

「To determine official transfers, the month’s *Yong-Shen* (用神) and the hour’s *Yong-Shen* are set as the critical period, with the hour where *Qing-Long* (青龙) descends marking the timing. Suppose *Cong-Kui* (从魁) descends upon *Wei* (未), and a civil official seeks to enter office and begin duties, while *Sheng-Xian* (胜先) is the hour where *Qing-Long* (青龙) descends; if *Jia-Geng* (甲庚) generates the hour, then the transfer is favorable.

The auspicious day is three hours away from *Qing-Long* (青龙) for a three-year transfer, and seven hours away for a seven-month *Qing-Long* (青龙). The *Yong-Shen* (用神) governing their residence is the Earthly Branch, and the hour where *Qiu-Wei* (戌) and *Si* (巳) meet with *Qing-Long* (青ong) is the critical time. After three years and seven months, on the *Wu-Yi* (戊己) day and hour, the transfer of *Tai-Chang* (太常) follows *Qing-Long* (青龙).

When the month generates *Qing-Long* (青龙) and *Tai-Chang* (太常), the transfer occurs externally. If *Qing-Long* (青ong) and *Tai-Chang* (太常) are generated on the same day, the transfer occurs internally—meaning an official promotion while seated. If this method is not fully observed, be cautious: do not allow *Cong-Kui* (从魁) to be misaligned, nor *Sheng-She* (剩蛇), *Bai-Hu* (白虎), or *Xuan-Wu* (玄武) to descend upon the day’s hour. If the *Yong-Shen* (用神) of the ruler’s year is *Xing* (行) and *E* (恶) aligns with its grave, it cannot be used.

The graves of *Jia-Yi* (甲乙) are in *Wei* (未), *Bing-Ding* (丙丁) in *Xu* (戌), *Geng-Xin* (庚辛) in *Chou* (丑), and those of *Ren-Gui* (壬癸) and *Wu-Yi* (戊己) all lie in *Zhen* (辰). The *Shen-Shu* (神枢) critical day is marked by calamity, and the period of concern is when *Qing-Long* (青龙) and *Tai-Chang* (太常) are in fear. The severity of being seated is determined by the Four Seasons’ *Qi* (气) of *Rest* (休), *Old* (老), *Imprisonment* (囚), and *Death* (死).

**Divination of Officials’ Auspiciousness and Transfers (Method XII):**
When the month’s *Yong-Shen* (用神) aligns with the day’s hour and the ruler’s year receives auspiciousness, if the *Yong-Shen* (用神) above and below harmonize, it is a great auspice. If the *Yong-Shen* (用神) also possesses *Wang-Xiang* (王相) *Qi* (气) and aligns with the direction of *Wang-Xiang* (王相), it indicates a transfer. Otherwise, it is inauspicious. If there is *Rest* (休) *Qi* (气), they may be spared from office; if *Bai* (退) and *Qiu* (罢) *Qi* (气) are present and the *Yong-Shen* (用神) above and below harm each other, there will be guilt and misfortune. If a guilty or fatal *Qi* (气) and an inauspicious *Yong-Shen* (用神) are encountered, but an auspicious *Yong-Shen* (用神) follows, it may bring salvation—this is a concern for external matters. If the day’s *Yong-Shen* (用神) possesses *Wang-Xiang* (王相) auspice, it indicates a transfer. If the ruler’s year’s *Yong-Shen* (用神) also possesses *Wang-Xiang* (王相) auspice, it also indicates a transfer. If both the day’s and the ruler’s year’s *Yong-Shen* (用神) are inauspicious, even if the hour’s *Yong-Shen* (用神) is benevolent, it still means no transfer. If the day’s hour, the ruler’s year, and the *Yong-Shen* (用神) are all auspicious, it confirms a transfer without doubt.

To determine the timing of a transfer, calculate the distance between *Cong-Kui* (从魁) and the day’s hour as the period. Suppose today’s hour is *Yin* (寅), and *Cong-Kui* (从魁) aligns with *Wu* (午); this means the transfer occurs five days later, or in the fifth month if applicable. *Jin-Gui* (金柜) states: "Does the transfer occur in this office?" meaning whether it pertains to civil or military officials. The *Shuo* (说) states: If both the day’s and the hour’s *Yong-Shen* (用神) possess *Wang-Xiang* (王相) *Qi* (气), it indicates a transfer for civil officials. If the *Yong-Shen* (用神) above the hour is inauspicious but possesses *Wang-Xiang* (王相) *Qi* (气), it indicates a transfer for military officials. If the *Yong-Shen* (用神) of the day, hour, and inauspicious hour all align, it means a double transfer. If the *Yong-Shen* (用神) aligns with *Meng-Zhong* (孟仲), the transfer occurs internally, and if it aligns with *Ji* (季), the transfer occurs externally.

**Divination of Officials’ Stability in Their Posts and Auspiciousness (Method XIII):**
If the *Yong-Shen* (用神) of the day’s hour and the ruler’s year receives auspiciousness and possesses *Wang-Xiang* (王相) *Qi* (气), it is auspicious. If *Rest* (休) or *Imprisonment* (囚) *Qi* (气) are present, it is inauspicious. The secondary *Yong-Shen* (用神) describes their appearance. Suppose they receive *Tian-Kui* (天魁) as *Bai-Hu* (白虎), indicating death and mourning; or *Xuan-Wu* (玄武), indicating loss and abandonment.

To determine who is auspicious or inauspicious, refer to the *Yong-Shen* (用神) of the ruler’s year: a Yang *Yong-Shen* (用神) represents the father, and a Yin *Yong-Shen* (用神) represents the mother. The *Shen-Shu* (神枢) principle states: Stability or instability is determined by the *Yong-Shen* (用神) of the officials and their direction, following this rule.

**Divination of Officials’ Stability in Their Posts (Method XIV):**
If the *Yong-Shen* (用神) of the day’s hour and the ruler’s year receive auspiciousness and the *Qi* (气) of *Rest* (休) or *Imprisonment* (囚) are absent, with the *Yong-Shen* (用神) above and below harmonizing, it indicates stability in office. If the *Yong-Shen* (用神) possesses *Wang-Xiang* (王相) *Qi* (气), it indicates a transfer. If the *Yong-Shen* (用神) is inauspicious but possesses *Wang-Xiang* (王相) *Qi* (气), and the *Yong-Shen* (用神) above and below harmonize, it still indicates stability in office. If the *Yong-Shen* (用神) above and below harm each other, it means instability in office. If both auspicious *Yong-Shen* (用神) and inauspicious *Yong-Shen* (用神) possess *Qi* (气) and the *Yong-Shen* (用神) above and below harm each other, it is even more inauspicious.

If there is *Passing* (传送), it indicates matters of travel and arrival; if there is *Zhu-Que* (朱雀), it indicates matters of speech and litigation; if there is *Xuan-Wu* (玄武), it indicates loss, abandonment, robbery, and suspicion.

*Guang-Ming-Fu* (光明符) states: If the month’s *Yong-Shen* (用神) aligns with the month’s *Jian* (建) and the ruler’s year exhibits *Rest* (休) or *Old* (老) *Qi* (气), it indicates dismissal from office. *Shen-Shu* (神枢) states: If both the day’s hour’s Yin-Yang and the *Yong-Shen* (用神) are in *Imprisonment* (囚), *Rest* (休), or *Decay* (废), they will lose their position.

**Divination of Officials’ Punishment, Execution, or Promotion (Method XV):**
If a ruler or their subordinates wish to carry out punishments or executions, they must first consult the timing. Do not allow *Tian-Yi* (天一) auspicious *Yong-Shen* (用神) or *Wang-Xiang* (王相) *Qi* (气) to descend upon the day’s hour. Auspicious *Yong-Shen* (用神) include *Gong-Cao* (功曹), *Sheng-Guang* (胜光), *Chuan-Song* (传送), *Shen-Hou* (神后), and *Da-Xiao-Ji* (大小吉). Auspicious *Yong-Shen* (用神) include *Tian-Yi* (天一), *Liu-He* (六合), *Qing-Long* (青龙), *Tai-Chang* (太常), *Tai-Yin* (太阴), and *Tian-Hou* (天后). None of these should be allowed to descend upon the day’s hour or the Yin of the hour. Additionally, the *Yong-Shen* (用神) of the hour’s Yin should not be allowed to harm.

If the *Yong-Shen* (用神) of the ruler’s year harms the *Yong-Shen* (用神) of the ruler’s year itself, it will inevitably bring harm to the body. Suppose the ruler’s year is *Wei* (未), and *Tai-Chong* (太冲) descends upon it, while today’s hour is *Si* (巳). If *Da-Ji* (大吉) descends upon *Si* (巳), it is a great auspice. If Yin is in *Chou* (丑) and *Cong-Kui* (从魁) descends upon *Chou* (丑), this means the Yin *Yong-Shen* (用神) harms the *Yong-Shen* (用神) of the ruler’s year. chunks.original_text: 正月辰时，腾蛇临今日之辰。 若玄武在日辰阴阳，皆为有贼盗。 欲知何党贼，以用上将言之。 用得白虎，杀人贼； 朱雀，烧人贼； 玄武，小盗。 在阳且有在阴，已有传得六合为不发。 若用神为囚气，所胜狱囚且坠亡。 君欲谋下害吏者，皆以用神处其福奇所在。 假令功曹为用，而得勾陈，当有贼在东北角。 他效此。 占诸杀人亡命可得以否法第十七 以其杀吉时，正月辰以玄武为主日辰，又其上神有制玄武者，为得日辰。 上下不制，玄武所临，为亡人。 假令二月丙申日人定时，河魁加亥，有杀人者。 时登明为玄武阴临子，亡人在北方。 丙上得天罡，申上得小吉，皆为土神，并克北方。 能制登明法，为戊己日得。 他效此。 占被盗无名盗可得否法第十八 以其亡时占之。 若不知亡时，以人未古？ 时占之。 正月时，以玄武、阴上神为盗神，日辰及年上神有制盗神者，可得。 假令十月甲子日人定时，功曹加亥。 亥上得后五将。 此时射盗，太一为太阴临甲，太冲为太常临子，天是为玄武临丑。 法以玄武阴上神为盗贼，小吉为天罡阴上神，小吉即盗也。 家在西南，为人黄色、羊目、多鬓、好出行。 今日甲木也，为制盗神。 子上神得太冲，太冲木也，亦克盗神。 凶盗不出刑中也，必得之。 日辰及年上神、不制盗神及玄武者，贼不可得也。 他效此。 占闻盗吉凶亡人所在欲捕得否法第十九 以闻知之时，射之今日，日辰、上神有克玄武所居神者，即得。 日辰及其上神无贼玄武所居神者，不得。 假令九月甲午日，日昳未时，太冲、加未，闻贼在其家。 魁为六合临甲，功曹为天后临午，天罡为玄武临申，天罡土神也，甲木日也。 功曹临午之木神也，并克玄武所居神为得。 贼不敢格战，当将兵马围贼家。 时兵马王当居神后上，击胜先下也。 假令到贼家时，一神后临酉，宜居贼家。 酉上东向，击卯地必胜获之。 他效此。 假令五一月甲寅日巳时，小吉加巳魁，为玄武甲寅木日辰也，并制玄武，贼必不敢斗也。 法背水攻火，又建今日辰，及起其后二，攻其前四。 假令今日甲子后二在戌，当从戌攻辰，是也。 又无令囚对王相攻，言夏壬癸不可向四维也。 他准此。 为囚死当王，一如秋甲乙不可西向攻盗贼也。 必以阴攻阳，背子亥登明、神后，向胜先、太一攻。 此当慎之。 自五月已下，皆式经正文。

**Divination of Theft or Robbery in Districts and Counties (Method XVII):**
In the *Chen* (辰) hour of the first month, the *Teng-She* (腾蛇) descends upon the day’s hour. If *Xuan-Wu* (玄武) is present in the day’s hour—whether in yin or yang—it signifies the presence of thieves.

To determine which faction the thieves belong to, observe the *Yong-Shen* (用神) of the *Shang-Jiang* (上将). If *Bai-Hu* (白虎) is used, it indicates murderous thieves; if *Zhu-Que* (朱雀), arsonists; if *Xuan-Wu*, petty thieves. If the ruler schemes to harm officials, observe where the *Yong-Shen* aligns with *Fu-Qi* (福奇). For instance, if *Gou-Chen* (勾陈) is used, thieves will be found in the northeast corner. Apply this method accordingly.

---

**Divination of Murder and Fugitives (Method XVIII):**
If the killing occurs during an auspicious hour, in the first month’s *Chen* (辰) hour, *Xuan-Wu* (玄武) governs the day’s hour. If the *Shang-Shen* (上神) restrains *Xuan-Wu*, it confirms the hour of the day. If neither restrains the other, *Xuan-Wu*’s descent signifies a fugitive.

For example, on a *Ren-Shen* (壬申) day in the second month at the *Ren-Ding* (人定) hour, if *He-Kui* (河魁) descends upon *Hai* (亥), a murderer will be present. *Deng-Ming* (登明) ascends as *Xuan-Wu* in yin upon *Zi* (子), placing the fugitive in the north. *Ren* (壬) above obtains *Tian-Gang* (天罡), *Shen* (申) above obtains *Xiao-Ji* (小吉)—both are earth deities, jointly restraining the north. If the method to restrain *Deng-Ming* is applied, it succeeds on *Wu-Ji* (戊己) days.

---

**Divination of Nameless Theft (Method XIX):**
Use the hour of the theft for divination. If the hour is unknown, use the *Ren-Wu* (人未) hour instead. In the first month, *Xuan-Wu* (玄武) and the yin *Shang-Shen* (上神) are the thief deities. If the day’s hour or the year’s *Shang-Shen* restrains the thief deity, the thief may be captured.

For example, on a *Jia-Zi* (甲子) day in the tenth month at the *Ren-Ding* (人定) hour, if *Gong-Cao* (功曹) descends upon *Hai* (亥) and obtains *Hou-Wu-Jiang* (后五将), this is the hour to shoot the thief. *Tai-Yi* (太一) is *Tai-Yin* (太阴) upon *Jia* (甲), *Tai-Chong* (太冲) is *Tai-Chang* (太常) upon *Zi* (子), and *Tian-Shi* (天市) is *Xuan-Wu* (玄武) upon *Chou* (丑). According to the method, *Xuan-Wu*’s yin *Shang-Shen* is the thief, while *Xiao-Ji* (小吉) is the *Tian-Gang* (天罡) yin *Shang-Shen*—thus, *Xiao-Ji* is the thief. The thief’s residence is in the southwest, with the thief described as yellow-skinned, with sheep-like eyes, a receding hairline, and fond of traveling. Today is *Jia-Mu* (甲木), restraining the thief deity. The *Shang-Shen* of *Zi* (子) obtains *Tai-Chong* (太冲), which is also wood and restrains the thief deity. The thief will not escape punishment and will be captured. If the day’s hour or the year’s *Shang-Shen* does not restrain the thief deity or *Xuan-Wu*, the thief cannot be captured.

---
**Divination of Hearing of Theft: Auspicious or Inauspicious, and the Fugitive’s Whereabouts (Method XX):**
Use the time when the theft is reported to shoot the thief today. If the day’s hour or its *Shang-Shen* restrains the deity residing where *Xuan-Wu* descends, the thief will be captured. If neither restrains the deity where *Xuan-Wu* resides, the thief will not be caught.

For example, on a *Jia-Wu* (甲午) day in the ninth month at the *Ri-Yi* (日昳) hour in *Wei* (未), if *Tai-Chong* (太冲) descends upon *Wei* and thieves are reported in their home, *Kui* (魁) is *Liu-He* (六合) upon *Jia* (甲), *Gong-Cao* (功曹) is *Tian-Hou* (天后) upon *Wu* (午), and *Tian-Gang* (天罡) is *Xuan-Wu* (玄武) upon *Shen* (申)—*Tian-Gang* is an earth deity, and *Jia* (甲) is a wood day. *Gong-Cao* upon *Wu* (午) is also a wood deity, jointly restraining the deity where *Xuan-Wu* resides, ensuring capture. The thief will not dare to resist; instead, surround the thief’s home with troops. The general commanding the troops should reside behind the deity’s position, striking first to ensure victory.

For example, upon arriving at the thief’s home, if a deity descends upon *You* (酉), it is auspicious to reside there. Facing east and striking the *Mao* (卯) direction will guarantee victory and capture.

For instance, on a *Jia-Yin* (甲寅) day in the fifth month at the *Si* (巳) hour, if *Xiao-Ji* (小吉) descends upon *Si* and *Kui* (魁) is present, *Xuan-Wu* is upon *Jia-Yin* (甲寅), a wood day and hour, jointly restraining *Xuan-Wu*—the thief will not dare to fight. Additionally, avoid positioning prisoners opposite the *Wang-Xiang* (王相) when attacking, as this is forbidden during summer for *Ren-Yi* (壬癸) days when attacking the four cardinal directions. Follow this principle accordingly. For prisoners facing execution, it is forbidden to attack westward during autumn for *Jia-Yi* (甲乙) days. Attack yin with yang, facing *Shen-Hou* (神后) and *Deng-Ming* (登明) from behind, and striking *Tai-Yi* (太一) and *Xing-Xian* (行先) first. Proceed with caution.

From the fifth month onward, all methods follow the *Shi-Jing Zheng-Wen* (式经正文).

chunks.original_text: 占六畜放牧自亡不知所在各随其类以其亡时占之第二十一 正月时，马责胜先之地，牛责大吉大责。 河魁鸡责从魁，羊责小吉，堵责登明。 欲知东西南北，各随其神所临。 在所胜之地为放纵，在所畏之地为拘系，在所生所喜之地为人逃匿之。 天一顺治责胜蛇，逆责玄武，为各随其所居神、日辰、上神，有制胜蛇、玄武及物类神者。 为得不制者，不得其物类。 神自临其日辰者，为归家。 其神与白虎，并临囚死之地，为死亡。 其神与六合、太阴，并为人欲隐藏之。 欲知远近，以其物类神所临，上不相乘为道理，数日辰上制物类神，为得日期。 假令三月壬申日中时，从魁加午时。 马自放责胜先，胜先临卯，式经云：东西南北各归其世是也。 为在东方。 胜先为午数九，卯数六，六九五十四里。 今日之辰，申上神得登明，为制胜先法。 壬癸、亥子日寻得。 假令先得壬癸，壬癸日得； 先得亥子，亥子日得。 又一法，以其神所来，乘为道里数。 临子午九，丑未八，寅申七，卯酉六，辰戌五，乃至巳亥四，此并为道里数也。 他效此。 假令今日日辰上神但致玄武、剩蛇； 不制物类之神，亦为得。 若制玄武、腾蛇，玄武等亦得。 两制者，保十必得，无疑也。 物类若驴骡，当责太冲也。 一云从魁为刀，太冲为项，神后为屠，太一为斧。 刀临项死，头临项不死，屠临釜死，釜临屠不死也。 假令六日壬寅日巳时，占失堵。 天一居太一而加辰，为顺治； 合责胜蛇居天罡而加卯，太冲为辰之阳神而克天罡。 此为日辰上神制胜蛇，所失堵果自归。 为登明加戌戌，与亥相近，故也。 他效此。 占诸欲知病人死生法第二十二 常以其初得病日时，占之。 假令胜蛇、白虎、魁罡克初病日，及占日日上神，人年所立辰，辰上神者，皆为死。 白虎所居神王相而贼初病日，及病人年、白虎、阴上神，又有气佐白虎，共克病日人年者，急呼妻子出，病者必不起，立死也。 死气为白虎克人年病日者，死。 又魁歪为白虎加病人元辰者，立死。 白虎非必在日辰阴阳中也，视直所居神，与病日人年相克以否。 假令不知初病时日，以今日日上神诀之。 今日日上神克病人行年，及年上神者，死。 阳命男，阴命女，以前八后六为元辰； 阴命男，阳命女，以前六后八为元辰。 假令阴命未生男，即从未至子，为前六后八。 他准此。 白虎所居神，贼今日，及人年上神，亦死。 若独贼病日之辰，不克，今日为愈。 说者云：白虎生初病日，病日生白虎，皆为病愈。 白虎贼病日人年，一一皆死。 白虎与病人年日辰相生，皆为愈； 与病日同类，为安久。 假令甲子日占病，登明、神后为白虎者，此为白虎生病日，病者不死春。 以胜先、太一为白虎者，此为病日生白虎，病者皆愈矣。 功曹、太冲为白虎者，此为同类，为病久。 白虎、阴阳皆有气，并伤日，立死； 不伤，立起。 白虎无气，病者愈。 假令白虎所居神，金也； 时秋有气。 若以甲子日占之，虽年及甲上有火神，火将恐死。 谓火至秋无气，恐不能救有气也。 此并式经文也。 假令不知病日人年所居立之辰，以今日用神诀之三传，终於白虎。 若日入墓者，为知吉凶期，以用神言之。 假令功曹直用，当丙丁日愈，庚辛日死。
chunks.translated_text:
Divination for the Six Livestock and Pasture Escape into the Unknown—Method Twenty-One

In the first month (正月), horses are held accountable in *Sheng-She* (胜蛇), cattle in *Da-Ji* (大吉) or *Da-Zui* (大罪). *He-Kui* (河魁) and chickens are held accountable in *Cong-Kui* (从魁), sheep in *Xiao-Ji* (小吉), and donkeys in *Deng-Ming* (登明).

To determine east, west, south, or north, follow the deity’s position. If in the *Sheng-She* (所胜) position, it indicates unrestrained grazing; if in the *Suo-Wei* (所畏) position, it means confinement. If in the *Sheng-Sheng* (所生) or *Suo-Xi* (所喜) positions, it signifies where humans will hide or lose them.

*Tian-Yi* (天一) aligns with *Shun-Zhi* (顺治) by holding *Sheng-She* (胜蛇) accountable, and opposes *Xuan-Wu* (玄武) by holding it accountable instead. This is done by following the deity’s position, the *Shen-Chen* (神辰), and the upper deity (*Shang-Shen* 上神), and determining which holds *Sheng-She* (胜蛇) or *Xuan-Wu* (玄武) accountable, or which deity is held accountable by them.

If no deity holds another accountable, the livestock will not be found. Deities that align with their respective *Shen-Chen* (神辰) indicate they have returned home.

If a deity coincides with *Bai-Hu* (白虎), and both align with the position of a prisoner’s death, it signifies death. If a deity coincides with *Liu-He* (六合) or *Tai-Yin* (太阴), it signifies where humans will conceal or hide them.

To determine distance, observe the deity’s position and upper deity (*Shang-Shen* 上神). If they do not conflict with each other, it is a straightforward path. If the *Shen-Chen* (神辰) and upper deity hold the deity accountable, it indicates the time of retrieval.

For example, on a *Ren-Shen* (壬申) day at noon (日中时), *Cong-Kui* (从魁) is added to *Wu* (午). Horses, having escaped, are held accountable in *Sheng-She* (胜先), which aligns with *Mao* (卯). As the *Shi-Jing* (式经) states: "Each direction returns to its own world," meaning the horses are in the east.

*Sheng-She* (胜先) corresponds to *Wu* (午) in the nine *Tian-Gan* (天罡) system, while *Mao* (卯) corresponds to six. Multiplying nine by six gives fifty-four *li* (里). Today’s *Shen-Chen* (神辰) and upper deity (*Shang-Shen* 上神) hold *Deng-Ming* (登明), which means they subdue *Sheng-She* (胜先). On *Ren-Gui* (壬癸) or *Hai-Zi* (亥子) days, the horses will be found. If *Sheng-She* (胜先) aligns with *Ren-Gui* (壬癸), they will be found on *Ren-Gui* days; if it aligns with *Hai-Zi* (亥子), they will be found on *Hai-Zi* days.

Another method: multiply the deity’s position by the distance to determine the *Dao-Li* (道里) count. If the deity aligns with *Zi-Wu* (子午) at nine, *Chou-Wei* (丑未) at eight, *Yin-Shen* (寅申) at seven, *Mao-You* (卯酉) at six, *Chen-Xu* (辰戌) at five, down to *Wei-Hai* (未亥) at four, these are the distance counts.

For example, if today’s *Shen-Chen* (神辰) and upper deity (*Shang-Shen* 上神) only hold *Xuan-Wu* (玄武) and *Sheng-She* (剩蛇) accountable, and do not hold the deity of the livestock accountable, it also means they will be found. If they hold *Xuan-Wu* (玄武) and *Teng-She* (腾蛇) accountable, those deities will also be found. When two deities hold others accountable, ten will definitely be found—no doubt.

If the livestock are mules or donkeys, hold *Tai-Chong* (太冲) accountable. Another saying: *Cong-Kui* (从魁) is the "knife," *Tai-Chong* (太冲) is the "neck," the deity behind is the "butcher," and *Tai-Yi* (太一) is the "axe." If the knife aligns with the neck, death occurs; if the head aligns with the neck, no death occurs. If the butcher aligns with the "cauldron" (*Fu* 釜), death occurs; if the cauldron aligns with the butcher, no death occurs.

For example, on a *Ren-Yin* (壬寅) day at *Si* (巳) hour, divining a lost donkey: *Tian-Yi* (天一) aligns with *Tai-Yi* (太一) and adds to *Chen* (辰), indicating *Shun-Zhi* (顺治); *He-Kui* (合) holds *Sheng-She* (胜蛇) accountable, aligning with *Tian-Gang* (天罡), and adds to *Mao* (卯). *Tai-Chong* (太冲) is the *Yang* (阳) deity of *Chen* (辰) and subdues *Tian-Gang* (天罡). This means the upper deity (*Shang-Shen* 上神) of today’s *Shen-Chen* (神辰) holds *Sheng-She* (胜蛇) accountable, and the lost donkey will indeed return. *Deng-Ming* (登明) adds to *Xu* (戌), which is close to *Hai* (亥), hence the retrieval.

---

Divination for Determining the Life or Death of Ill Patients—Method Twenty-Two

Always use the patient’s initial illness day and hour for divination. For example, if *Sheng-She* (胜蛇), *Bai-Hu* (白虎), or *Kui-Gang* (魁罡) hold the initial illness day and hour accountable, or if the divination day’s upper deity (*Shang-Shen* 上神) holds the patient’s birth *Shen-Chen* (神辰) or its upper deity accountable, it signifies death.

If *Bai-Hu* (白虎) aligns with the deity of the divination day and holds the initial illness day accountable, or if the patient’s birth year, *Bai-Hu* (白虎), and the *Yin* (阴) upper deity align, and there is *Qi* (气) assisting *Bai-Hu* (白虎), collectively holding the patient’s birth year accountable, urgently summon the patient’s wife and children—the patient will not recover and will die immediately.

If the *Qi* (气) of death is *Bai-Hu* (白虎) holding the patient’s birth year and initial illness day accountable, it signifies death. Additionally, if *Kui-Wai* (魁歪) adds to the patient’s birth *Shen-Chen* (元辰), it also signifies immediate death.

*Bai-Hu* (白虎) is not necessarily bound by *Yin-Yang* (阴阳) positions; observe its direct alignment with the deity and whether it holds the patient’s birth year or initial illness day accountable.

If the initial illness day and hour are unknown, use today’s upper deity (*Shang-Shen* 上神) to determine by three transmissions, concluding at *Bai-Hu* (白虎). If the day enters the *Mu* (墓), it indicates knowing the period of good or bad fortune, determined by the deity in use.

For example, if *Gong-Cao* (功曹) is directly in use, recovery will occur on *Bing-Ding* (丙丁) days, and death on *Geng-Xin* (庚辛) days.

If *Bai-Hu* (白虎) aligns with the deity of the patient’s birth year or today’s upper deity (*Shang-Shen* 上神), it also signifies death. If *Bai-Hu* (白虎) only holds the initial illness day’s *Shen-Chen* (神辰) accountable and does not subdue it, today indicates recovery.

Some say: If *Bai-Hu* (白虎) aligns with the initial illness day or the initial illness day aligns with *Bai-Hu* (白虎), it signifies recovery from illness. If *Bai-Hu* (白虎) holds the patient’s birth year and initial illness day accountable, it signifies death. If *Bai-Hu* (白虎) aligns with the patient’s birth year or day and *Shen-Chen* (神辰) in harmony, it signifies recovery; if it aligns with the same category as the illness day, it signifies prolonged illness.

For example, if divining on a *Jia-Zi* (甲子) day for an illness, *Deng-Ming* (登明) and *Shen-Hou* (神后) align with *Bai-Hu* (白虎), this means *Bai-Hu* (白虎) aligns with the illness day, and the patient will not die in spring. If *Sheng-She* (胜先) and *Tai-Yi* (太一) align with *Bai-Hu* (白虎), this means the illness day aligns with *Bai-Hu* (白虎), and the patient will recover. If *Gong-Cao* (功曹) and *Tai-Chong* (太冲) align with *Bai-Hu* (白虎), this means they are of the same category, indicating prolonged illness.

*Bai-Hu* (白虎) and *Yin-Yang* (阴阳) both have *Qi* (气). If they collectively harm the day, the patient will die immediately; if they do not harm the day, the patient will recover immediately.

If *Bai-Hu* (白虎) lacks *Qi* (气), the patient will recover. For example, if *Bai-Hu* (白虎) aligns with a deity of *Jin* (金), and it is autumn with *Qi* (气) present, even if the year and *Jia* (甲) upper deity hold a deity of *Huo* (火), the fire deity will fear death. This is because fire in autumn lacks *Qi* (气) and cannot save the deity with *Qi* (气). These are all from the *Shi-Jing* (式经).

If the patient’s birth year and initial illness day’s *Shen-Chen* (神辰) are unknown, use today’s deity in use to determine by three transmissions, concluding at *Bai-Hu* (白虎).

chunks.original_text: 又天一为用，生气在丑未。 辰戌之日腾蛇为用，死在巳亥日。 他效此。 又一法，不知初病日时，以人来问时占之，日辰人年临其墓，亦为死日。 人年所立辰之阴阳神入其墓者，亦死日。 墓还临其日辰者，亦死年。 墓还地年者，亦死。 假令甲乙日射病时，天上甲乙临未，为日入其墓。 若小吉临甲乙，为墓其日也。 假令病者，年立子问事时，神后临辰，为年所立之辰，阴阳神入其墓。 若天罡加子为墓临其年，皆死辰。 墓效日墓之列。 又一法，用神始终，得日墓皆凶。 天罡击今日日墓，为墓门开，亦死。 甲乙寅卯木墓在未，丙丁巳午火墓在戌。 余支干准此之例也。 小吉木墓，河魁火墓，大吉金墓，天罡为水土之墓。 式经曰：白虎、阴阳有气，伤病。 日人年者，死。 人年上神王相克白虎者，愈。 病日生白虎者，亦愈。 白虎生病日者，死。 白虎与病日同类者，为之安久也。 占知囚系罪轻重法第二十三 式经云：先建系日日辰、阴惕，风取其当者，而传其始终。 终休罪重，终因加罪，终死罪重后轻。 正日时，视用神终於王相之气，贵人救之，元罪。 终於休气，罪重。 终於囚气，加罪。 终於死气，先重后轻。 终於腾蛇，罪重，无疑必死。 终於朱雀，数见掠笞。 终於勾陈，有所勾连。 终於玄武，置辞而亡。 终於天空，空无所有。 有实也。 终於白虎，被罪至死。 终於吉将，传得其子为有救，罪得解。 传入其狱为有罪，传得他狱为移狱。 所为狱者，墓也。 假令功曹、太冲小吉为狱，登明、神后即天罡是其狱。 他例此。 所谓移狱者，假令起功曹，终於河魁，为移狱。 一法以初系日占之，各以其所犯为坐。 假令斗伤人，以勾陈杀人以白虎窃盗以玄武相告罪名以朱雀。 假令犯坐伤，以勾陈所居神贼系，日即论也。 系日贼勾陈者，不论也。 勾陈与日同类，为系久。 传神得其狱者，必论。 假令以甲乙日系，天一居小吉临未； 系日丙丁，天一临戌； 系日庚辛，天一临丑； 系日壬癸，天一临辰； 系日戊己，天一亦临辰； 为必离讼狱，传勾陈之阴，得白虎，白虎所居之神与勾陈并贼，其系日者死。 式经曰：假令以甲乙日系勾陈所居在金神上者，此为勾陈胜系日者，即被论罪也。 若勾陈居土神上者，此为系日胜勾陈，即免被论罪也。 传勾陈之阴； 得天一，天一生系日日辰者，为贵人救之也。 传勾陈得系日子，母人将哀一反，可为上书也。 假令七月己未日食时，传送为太常临巳，谓日辰上共得后四之将。 神将不相刑又有王相气，谓金玉故也。 天罡为勾陈加卯，传得其母。 谓辰上得太一也。 勾陈与日同类，法为安久。 不然，蒙听令。 欲知吉凶之期者，以用神传，终为有救神期也。 假令七月己未日酉时，天一治神后加於辰，太冲亦加今日日辰，神将不相刑，有王气传得其母，登明加卯故也。 勾陈与日同类，法当系久。 然蒙得出传，而得传送天一，为移狱也。 占诸欲远行使出吉门法第二十四 始行时，欲令今日日辰人年上得吉神将，有王相休气而出小吉，得传送下，即大吉。 慎无令魁罡临所出门上，所出门上之神，又不可伤行者年上神。 门上神者，所出入门也。 假令八月甲申日时，卯正日时，行者年立戌，戌上得登明，欲伤行之午，午上得小吉，小吉伤登明，此为门上神伤行者年上神也。

When *Tian-Yi* (天一) is in use, its vital *qi* (气) lies in *Chou* (丑) and *Wei* (未). On days of *Chen* (辰) and *Xu* (戌), *Teng-She* (腾蛇) is in use, and death occurs on days of *Si* (巳) and *Hai* (亥). Other cases follow this pattern.

Another method: if the initial illness day and time are unknown, determine by the time the patient arrives for consultation. If the patient’s birth year, current day, and hour all fall into the *Mu* (墓) of the deity in use, it is a death day. If the *Yin-Yang* (阴阳) deity of the patient’s birth year’s *Shen-Chen* (神辰) enters its *Mu* (墓), it is also a death day. If the *Mu* (墓) returns to the patient’s birth year’s *Shen-Chen*, it is also a death year. If the *Mu* (墓) returns to the patient’s birth year, it is also a death.

For example, if illness occurs on *Jia* (甲) or *Yi* (乙) days, and *Tian-Shang* (天上) *Jia* (甲) or *Yi* (乙) aligns with *Wei* (未), it means the day has entered its *Mu* (墓). If *Xiao-Ji* (小吉) aligns with *Jia* (甲) or *Yi* (乙), it means the day is in *Mu* (墓). If a patient’s birth year is established on *Zi* (子) and is being consulted, and the deity *Hou* (后) aligns with *Chen* (辰), it means the *Shen-Chen* (神辰) of the birth year’s *Yin-Yang* (阴阳) deity has entered its *Mu* (墓). If *Tian-Gang* (天罡) aligns with *Zi* (子) as the *Mu* (墓) of the birth year, it is also a death day. The *Mu* (墓) follows the same sequence as the day’s *Mu* (墓).

Another method: if the deity in use begins and ends with the day’s *Mu* (墓), it is ominous. If *Tian-Gang* (天罡) strikes the day’s *Mu* (墓), it means the *Mu* (墓) gate is open—also a death omen. The *Mu* (墓) of *Jia* (甲) and *Yi* (乙) *Le-Mao* (寅卯) wood is in *Wei* (未); the *Mu* (墓) of *Bing* (丙) and *Ding* (丁) *Si-Wu* (巳午) fire is in *Xu* (戌). The remaining branches follow this pattern. *Xiao-Ji* (小吉) is the *Mu* (墓) of wood, *He-Kui* (河魁) is the *Mu* (墓) of fire, *Da-Ji* (大吉) is the *Mu* (墓) of metal, and *Tian-Gang* (天罡) is the *Mu* (墓) of water and earth.

*The Shi-Jing* (式经) states:
If *Bai-Hu* (白虎) and *Yin-Yang* (阴阳) have *qi* (气) and harm the patient, death occurs. If the day enters the patient’s birth year, death follows. If the upper deities of the birth year and the patient’s *Shen-Chen* (神辰) restrain *Bai-Hu* (白虎), recovery occurs. If *Bai-Hu* (白虎) is born on the illness day, death follows. If *Bai-Hu* (白虎) and the illness day share the same element, the patient will be stable for a long time.

**Method Twenty-Three: Determining the Severity of Imprisonment and Crime**
*The Shi-Jing* (式经) states: First, establish the day and hour of imprisonment, along with *Yin-Tu* (阴惕). Use *Feng* (风) to determine the corresponding deity and trace its beginning and end. If it ends in *Xiu* (休), the crime is severe. If it ends in *Yin* (因), additional punishment is added. If it ends in *Si* (死), the crime is severe but later mitigated. If it ends in *Teng-She* (腾蛇), the crime is severe, and death is certain. If it ends in *Zhu-Que* (朱雀), repeated beatings occur. If it ends in *Gou-Chen* (勾陈), there are entanglements. If it ends in *Xuan-Wu* (玄武), the accused will perish after a trial. If it ends in *Tian-Kong* (天空), there is no substance—only emptiness. If it ends in *Bai-Hu* (白虎), the accused will face charges leading to death. If it ends in *Ji-Jiang* (吉将), if the transmission reaches their child, salvation is possible, and the crime is pardoned. If it enters prison, the accused is guilty. If it reaches another prison, the case is transferred. The so-called "prison" refers to *Mu* (墓).

For example, if *Gong-Cao* (功曹) or *Tai-Chong* (太冲) *Xiao-Ji* (小吉) is the prison, *Deng-Ming* (登明) or *Shen-Hou* (神后) is the *Tian-Gang* (天罡) prison. Other cases follow this pattern. The "transfer of prison" means, for instance, beginning with *Gong-Cao* (功曹) and ending with *He-Kui* (河魁)—this is a transfer of prison.

One method involves using the initial day of imprisonment to determine the charge. For example, if a fight occurs, *Gou-Chen* (勾陈) is responsible for homicide; *Bai-Hu* (白虎) for theft; *Xuan-Wu* (玄武) for slander; and *Zhu-Que* (朱雀) for false accusations. If the accused is charged with assault, the deity residing in *Gou-Chen* (勾陈) is the culprit, and judgment follows. If the culprit is *Gou-Chen* (勾陈) on the day of imprisonment, no judgment is passed. If *Gou-Chen* (勾陈) shares the same element as the day, imprisonment will be prolonged. If the transmitted deity reaches its prison, judgment is certain.

For example, if imprisonment occurs on *Jia* (甲) or *Yi* (乙) days, *Tian-Yi* (天一) resides in *Xiao-Ji* (小吉) and aligns with *Wei* (未); if imprisonment occurs on *Bing* (丙) or *Ding* (丁) days, *Tian-Yi* (天一) aligns with *Xu* (戌); if imprisonment occurs on *Geng* (庚) or *Xin* (辛) days, *Tian-Yi* (天一) aligns with *Chou* (丑); if imprisonment occurs on *Ren* (壬) or *Gui* (癸) days, *Tian-Yi* (天一) aligns with *Chen* (辰); if imprisonment occurs on *Wu* (戊) or *Ji* (己) days, *Tian-Yi* (天一) also aligns with *Chen* (辰). This means the accused will inevitably face litigation, and if *Gou-Chen* (勾陈) transmits its *Yin* (阴) to *Bai-Hu* (白虎), and the deity residing in *Bai-Hu* (白虎) aligns with *Gou-Chen* (勾陈) and the culprit, the accused on the imprisonment day will die.

*The Shi-Jing* (式经) states: If imprisonment occurs on *Jia* (甲) or *Yi* (乙) days and *Gou-Chen* (勾陈) resides on a metal deity, this means *Gou-Chen* (勾陈) overpowers the imprisonment day, and the accused will be convicted. If *Gou-Chen* (勾陈) resides on an earth deity, this means the imprisonment day overpowers *Gou-Chen* (勾陈), and the accused will be acquitted. If *Gou-Chen* (勾陈) transmits its *Yin* (阴) and reaches *Tian-Yi* (天一), and *Tian-Yi* (天一) generates the imprisonment day’s *Shen-Chen* (神辰), this means a noble saves the accused. If *Gou-Chen* (勾陈) transmits to the imprisonment day’s *Zi* (子), the mother will grieve, and a petition can be made.

For example, on the seventh month’s *Ji-Wei* (己未) day during a solar eclipse, if *Tai-Chang* (太常) aligns with *Si* (巳), it means the day’s *Shen-Chen* (神辰) collectively obtains the later four deities. The deities do not clash, and there is *Wang-Xiang* (王相) *qi* (气), meaning metal and jade. *Tian-Gang* (天罡) aligns with *Mao* (卯) as *Gou-Chen* (勾陈), and its transmission reaches its mother—meaning *Tai-Yi* (太一) is obtained on *Chen* (辰). If *Gou-Chen* (勾陈) shares the same element as the day, by law, imprisonment will be prolonged. Otherwise, the accused will be pardoned. To know the period of fortune or misfortune, trace the deity in use. If it ends with a deity of salvation, that is the period.

For example, on the seventh month’s *Ji-Wei* (己未) day at *You* (酉) hour, *Tian-Yi* (天一) governs *Shen-Hou* (神后) and aligns with *Chen* (辰), while *Tai-Chong* (太冲) also aligns with the day’s *Shen-Chen* (神辰). However, if *Tian-Yi* (天一) is transmitted, it means the prison is transferred.

**Method Twenty-Four: Determining Auspicious Departure Gates for Travel**
At the start of a journey, if the day’s *Shen-Chen* (神辰), the traveler’s birth year, and the deity in use obtain a *Ji* (吉) deity, with *Wang-Xiang* (王相) and *Xiu* (休) *qi* (气), and *Xiao-Ji* (小吉) is transmitted downward, it becomes *Da-Ji* (大吉). Be cautious not to have *Kui-Gang* (魁罡) align with the departure gate. The deity of the departure gate must not harm the traveler’s birth year deity. The "gate deity" refers to the deity of the entrance and exit.

For example, on the eighth month’s *Jia-Shen* (甲申) day at *Mao* (卯) hour, the traveler’s birth year is established on *Xu* (戌), and *Xu* (戌) obtains *Deng-Ming* (登明). If it harms the traveler’s *Wu* (午), and *Wu* (午) obtains *Xiao-Ji* (小吉), while *Xiao-Ji* (小吉) harms *Deng-Ming* (登明), this means the gate deity harms the traveler’s birth year deity.

chunks.original_text: 又法，欲将帅出行，欲令天罡临四季为神枢，外百事吉。 神枢又云：元令所之之乡伤其年，乃有喜。 假令欲行，行人年立四季，此为所之之乡伤共年也。 他效此。 占诸欲行求事者第二十五 以始行正日时，元令今日辰上神伤行者年之所立地辰，所立地辰，亦勿令伤辰上神。 若伤辰上神，是谓相刑，其事不成也。 假令年立巳，而今日丙寅，神后临寅，此辰上之神伤人年所立地辰也。 假令是日时，神后临寅，人年立辰，此为年所立地辰伤辰上神也。 法欲有求作者，欲令今日日辰阴阳及用传中，有其事类。 事类者，谓求财。 欲得青龙小吉，求缯彩； 欲得太常，求蚕； 欲得胜光之比也。 故式经云：展上神伤其地年所求难得，后自亡遗。 占诸望行者吉凶来否第二十六 必当视所至地之阳神，以卯为限，以子午上神为至期。 东方、南方以酉为限，子上神为至期。 西方、北方以卯为限，午上神为至期。 假令望酉地，人从魁加戌为巳发，加子为半道，加卯为得限，当来以午上神为至期。 午上神得神后，以壬癸亥子日至。 假令望巳地，人太一加午为巳发，加酉为得限，当来以子上神为至期。 子上得传送，期庚辛申酉日至。 假令望寅地，人功曹加酉为来； 望申地，人传送加卯为来； 望子地，人神后加卯为来； 望午地，人胜先加酉为来； 皆以子午上神为至期。 诸望行者过限，皆以为闻其闻，为不来也。 要所至事类，度为不来。 所为事类者，望贵人，以天； 亦为望父。 望父母，以太常； 望兄弟，以太阴； 望妇女，以天后； 望子孙，以六合； 望友及夫、钱财、二千石等，以青龙； 望盗，以玄武； 望死丧，以白虎； 望奴婢，以天空； 下亦同使。 望吏捕人，以朱雀； 望行道还，以胜蛇； 望斗战； 以勾陈并以所加今日日辰，以比为来； 传以为至，其度限为不来也。 集灵记云：几望行人以甲乙日占，用得巳午神者，为将至； 用亥子神者，为背日； 背日为不至也。 金匮云：至不至问前四。 言甲午日前四戌戌上所见神为至期。 假今戌上见功曹，则寅上至。 一说云：应至而不至，乃用此法也。 又云：占行人以生王为至期。 假令用起水神，则甲子日至。 遇墓者，则不来。 假令壬癸日，用起天是、为遇墓。 遇墓，即止而不来。 史苏经日：卜外人以生王而至，卜家人遇墓亦至也。 凡占吉凶赊促所之远近，皆以计神占之。 计神者，河魁是也。 故金匮云：数以魁离日，假令魁加未，未数八，魁数五，五八四十为吉，凶在四十日内。 行人当之为四百里也。 他皆仿此也。 一说云：魁罡离初发日为期日，临而发日，即日至也。 又法，居外望内人，以夏至辰之阴神； 居内望外人，以冬至辰之阳神临今日日辰，日辰与太冲临未，皆为来。 假令夏至以卯，卯之阳神太冲、今日丙丁太冲临寅为本，临午为中，临戌为末，皆为来也。 假令太冲临午，当以丙丁巳午日，至月期五月。 假令冬至以午，午之阳神，胜先也。 今日甲乙，胜先临亥为本，临卯为中，临未为末，皆来。 假令胜先临亥，当以壬癸亥子日，至月期十月。 一法，望行者，天罡系今日日辰，为今日至，顺系日辰至逆系、日辰，为不至。 所谓逆顺者，假令望西方人，天罡系北方，东方日辰为顺，顺即来系南方，西方为逆；

When leading an expedition, one must ensure that the **Celestial Ganges (天罡)** aligns with the four seasons as the **Divine Pivot (神枢)**, making all external matters auspicious. The **Divine Pivot** further states: If the direction of travel harms the year of the traveler’s birth, there will be joy.

For example, if one wishes to travel and the traveler’s birth-year aligns with the season of the destination, this is when the direction of travel harms their birth-year. Others follow this pattern.

**Divination for those seeking matters while traveling (25th method):**
At the start of the journey, on the exact day and hour, if the **Divine Pivot (神)** of today’s *Chen* (辰) harms the birth-year’s *Chen* of the traveler’s birthplace, or if the birthplace’s *Chen* harms the *Chen*’s **Divine Pivot**, this is called **mutual assault (相刑)**, and the matter will not succeed.

For example, if the traveler’s birth-year aligns with *Wei* (巳), and today is *Bing-Yin* (丙寅), with the **Divine Pivot** descending upon *Yin* (寅), this is when the *Chen*’s **Divine Pivot** harms the birth-year’s *Chen* of the traveler’s birthplace.
If today’s hour has the **Divine Pivot** descending upon *Yin* (寅), and the birth-year’s *Chen* is *Wei* (巳), this is when the birthplace’s *Chen* harms the *Chen*’s **Divine Pivot**.

For those who seek matters, one must ensure that today’s *yin-yang* of the *Chen* and the **transmission (传送)** align with the category of the matter sought.
The **category of the matter (事类)** refers to seeking wealth:
- To obtain **Small Auspiciousness (青龙小吉)**, seek **silk fabrics (缯彩)**;
- To obtain **Grand Harmony (太常)**, seek **silkworms (蚕)**;
- To obtain **Victorious Light (胜光)** and its comparisons.

Thus, the *Shi Li Jing* states: If the **Divine Pivot** harms the land of the birth-year’s sought matter, it will be difficult to obtain, and loss will follow.

**Divination for the auspiciousness or ill-fortune of distant travelers (26th method):**
One must observe the **yang deity (阳神)** of the destination. For the **East and South**, set *You* (酉) as the limit, with the **Deity of Child (子上神)** as the arrival period.
For the **West and North**, set *Mao* (卯) as the limit, with the **Deity of Noon (午上神)** as the arrival period.

For example, if traveling to a place marked by *You* (酉), the traveler departs when *Kui* (魁) aligns with *Xu* (戌) as *Wei* (巳), aligns with *Zi* (子) as halfway, and aligns with *Mao* (卯) as the limit. The arrival is determined by the **Deity of Noon (午上神)**, reaching its peak on *Ren-Gui* (壬癸) days of *Hai-Zi* (亥子).

If traveling to a place marked by *Wei* (巳), the traveler departs when *Tai-Yi* (太一) aligns with *Wu* (午) as *Wei* (巳), aligns with *You* (酉) as the limit. The arrival is determined by the **Deity of Child (子上神)**, reaching its peak on *Geng-Xin* (庚辛) days of *Shen-You* (申酉).

If traveling to a place marked by *Yin* (寅), the traveler arrives when *Gong-Cao* (功曹) aligns with *You* (酉).
If traveling to a place marked by *Shen* (申), the traveler arrives when **transmission (传送)** aligns with *Mao* (卯).
If traveling to a place marked by *Zi* (子), the traveler arrives when **Divine Pivot (神后)** aligns with *Mao* (卯).
If traveling to a place marked by *Wu* (午), the traveler arrives when *Sheng-Xian* (胜先) aligns with *You* (酉).
All arrivals are determined by the **Deity of Child (子上神)** and **Deity of Noon (午上神)** as the peak periods.

If travelers exceed the limit, it is considered as if they were heard of but did not arrive. The **category of the matter (事类)** is also deemed not to arrive.

The **categories of matters (事类)** are as follows:
- Seeking a noble person or one’s father: **Celestial Deity (天)**;
- Seeking parents: **Grand Harmony (太常)**;
- Seeking siblings: **Great Yin (太阴)**;
- Seeking women: **Empress Mother (天后)**;
- Seeking children and grandchildren: **Six Harmonies (六合)**;
- Seeking friends, husbands, money, or officials of the second rank: **Azure Dragon (青龙)**;
- Seeking thieves: **Dark Turtle (玄武)**;
- Seeking death or mourning: **White Tiger (白虎)**;
- Seeking slaves: **Celestial Void (天空)**;
- Seeking officials to capture a person: **Vermilion Bird (朱雀)**;
- Seeking safe return from travel: **Victorious Serpent (胜蛇)**;
- Seeking battles: **Hooked Array (勾陈)**, determined by the alignment with today’s *Chen* and hour, comparing for arrival;
- **Transmission (传)** marks the arrival, while exceeding the limit marks non-arrival.

The *Ji Ling Ji* states: For those awaiting travelers, if divined on *Jia-Yi* (甲乙) days and the **Deities of Wei-Wu (巳午)** are obtained, it means they are approaching. If the **Deities of Hai-Zi (亥子)** are obtained, it means they are turning back, and turning back means they will not arrive.

The *Golden Cabinet (金匮)* states: For questions of arrival or non-arrival, observe the four deities before the day. If on a *Jia-Wu* (甲午) day, the deity seen on *Xu* (戌) four days prior is *Gong-Cao* (功曹), then arrival will be upon *Yin* (寅).

Another saying states: If one should arrive but does not, this method applies. It further states: For divining travelers, use the **Birth King (生王)** as the arrival period. For example, if the **Water God (起水神)** is used, arrival will be on *Jia-Zi* (甲子) days. If encountering a **grave (墓)**, they will not come. For example, on *Ren-Gui* (壬癸) days, if the **Celestial Deity (天是)** is used, it means encountering a grave, and they will not arrive.

The *Shi Su Jing* states: Divining outsiders with the **Birth King (生王)** means they will arrive; divining family members encountering a grave also means they will arrive.

In general, divining auspiciousness, ill-fortune, delays, or the distance of travel is all determined by calculating the **River Marshal (河魁)**.

The *Golden Cabinet (金匮)* states: Count the days from *Kui* (魁). For example, if *Kui* aligns with *Wei* (未), *Wei* is eight, and *Kui* is five; five multiplied by eight equals forty, which is auspicious. Ill-fortune lies within forty days. The traveler’s journey will be four hundred *li*.

Others follow this pattern. Another saying states: The **River Marshal (魁罡)** departs from the initial day of travel as the period day. If it aligns with the departure day, arrival will be immediate.

Another method states: For those residing outside awaiting someone inside, use the **yin deity (阴神)** of the *Chen* at the Summer Solstice. For those residing inside awaiting someone outside, use the **yang deity (阳神)** of the *Chen* at the Winter Solstice aligning with today’s *Chen*. If the *Chen* and **Tai-Chong (太冲)** align with *Wei* (未), they will arrive.

For example, if the Summer Solstice is at *Mao* (卯), the **yang deity (阳神)** *Tai-Chong* (太冲) of *Mao* (卯) is the root, today’s *Bing-Ding* (丙丁) *Tai-Chong* (太冲) descending upon *Yin* (寅) is the root, descending upon *Wu* (午) is the middle, descending upon *Xu* (戌) is the end—all mean arrival.

If *Tai-Chong* (太冲) descends upon *Wu* (午), it will arrive on *Bing-Ding* (丙丁) days of *Wei-Wu* (巳午), reaching the monthly period in five months.

If the Winter Solstice is at *Wu* (午), the **yang deity (阳神)** is *Sheng-Xian* (胜先). Today’s *Jia-Yi* (甲乙), with *Sheng-Xian* (胜先) descending upon *Hai* (亥) as the root, descending upon *Mao* (卯) as the middle, descending upon *Wei* (未) as the end—all mean arrival.

If *Sheng-Xian* (胜先) descends upon *Hai* (亥), it will arrive on *Ren-Gui* (壬癸) days of *Hai-Zi* (亥子), reaching the monthly period in ten months.

Another method states: For awaiting travelers, if the **Celestial Ganges (天罡)** aligns with today’s *Chen* as the arrival day, and if it aligns in reverse with the *Chen*, they will not arrive.

The **reverse and forward (逆顺)** refers to this: For example, if awaiting someone from the West, the **Celestial Ganges (天罡)** aligns with the North. The *Chen* of the East is forward, meaning they will arrive; aligning with the South is reverse, meaning they will not arrive; aligning with the West is forward, meaning they will arrive; aligning with the North is reverse, meaning they will not arrive.

**Method 29: Determining Auspiciousness or Inauspiciousness for Construction and All Matters**

Examine the **hourly stem-branch (正日时)**—ensure that the **current year’s Tai Sui (太岁) yang spirit (阳神)** does not govern the **hourly stem-branch of the day** or the **land to be treated**. If it does, the household will be **annihilated within twelve years**.

Further, ensure that **Kui Gang (魁罡), Teng She (腾蛇), or Bai Hu (白虎)** do not govern the **hourly stem-branch of the day**, for this is **greatly inauspicious**.

If **Da Ji (大吉), Sheng Xian (胜先), or Gong Cao (功曹)** align with the **yin-yang of the hourly stem-branch** and harmonize with it, then it is **greatly auspicious**. Otherwise, it is inauspicious.

For entering dwellings, apply the same method.

By examining the **upper generals (上神将)**, one determines the nature of the **auspicious or inauspicious generals (吉凶将)**:
- If **Bai Hu (白虎)** is encountered, there will be **many deaths and mourning**.
- If **Xuan Wu (玄武)** is encountered, there will be **many losses and abandonment**.
- If **Gou Chen (勾陈)** is encountered, there will be **many lawsuits**.
- If **Zhu Que (朱雀)** is encountered, there will be **quarrels, litigation, and official troubles**.
- If **Teng She (腾蛇)** is encountered, there will be **strange occurrences**.
- If **Tian Kong (天空)** is encountered, there will be **decline and depletion**, failed ventures, and livestock will not thrive.
- If **Zhu Que (朱雀)** aligns with **Deng Ming (登明) or Tian Yi (天一)** in conjunction with the dwelling, it will bring **punishment**. If using the **Zhi Yong Shen (直用神)** from the *Zhongshu* transmission, there is salvation. For those who come afterward, they must **avoid it**.

For example, if the **Tai Sui is in Mao (卯)** this year, and on the **eighth month, Jia Xū day (甲戌)**, during **daybreak (日出时)**, **Tian Gang (天罡)** governs **Mao (卯)**. If one constructs or covers a house, **Tai Chong (太冲)**, as the **Tai Sui yang spirit**, governs **Jia (甲)**, encountering **Zhu Que (朱雀)**. **Kui (魁)**, as **Xuan Wu (玄武)**, governs **You (酉)**, while the **yin-yang of the hourly stem-branch** lacks **Da Ji (大吉), Sheng Xian (胜先), or Gong Cao (功曹)**. Moreover, the **Tai Sui yang spirit** governs the **hourly stem-branch of the day**, making all matters **greatly inauspicious**. If, on that day, one intends to treat **Yin (寅) land for residence**, it falls under the **Tai Sui yang spirit’s governance**, and thus is also **greatly inauspicious**. Apply the same method elsewhere.

**Method 30: Determining Whether a Dwelling is Habitable**

Examine the **hourly stem-branch (正日时)** and the **yin spirit of the upper general (上神神阴)**. If an **auspicious general (吉神将)** is present, with **Wang Xiang (王相) and resting qi (休气)**, and the upper position **generates (相生)**, then it is **auspicious to reside**. If a **malevolent general (凶神)** is present, with **prison or death qi (囚死气)**, and the upper and lower positions **harm (相贼)**, then it is **inauspicious and uninhabitable**.

By examining the **extremes (尤者)**, one discerns their manifestations:
- If **Bai Hu (白虎)** is present, there will be **death and mourning**.
- If **Tian Kong (天空)** is present, there will be **emptiness and depletion**.
Apply the same method elsewhere.

chunks.original_text: 占田蚕种五谷好恶法第三十一 正日时，欲令今日日辰上神多王相气，与所欲为物类神相生。 又欲天一所居神，与太岁上神相生物类神，即大吉。 日辰阴阳及用传中有其物，必成熟也。 无令魁、罡、剩蛇、白虎、囚死之气，临日辰者凶。 物类者，谓蚕以胜先，禾以功曹、太冲，黍、小豆以太一、胜先，麦以传送、从魁，稻、大豆以登明、神后，麻以大吉、小吉。 假令欲占蚕，日辰阴阳及用传中有胜先，因而三传胜先，皆得吉神将，得天一所居神与太岁上神相生胜先，即大吉也。 假令太岁在辰，四月戊辰日中时，传送临午，占蚕善恶何？ 如胜先临辰，此为有其物类。 太岁上神自得胜先，将得青龙神将相生，天一在大吉，不与胜先相克，则为大岁。 日辰上神皆有王相之气，无有灾害，诸物类等，并效此。 也若物类神与太岁上神相贼，天一所居神克日辰，阴阳中无其事类，则为大凶败也。 占今年举百事商贾田蚕法第三十二 皆以日辰及家长年上神将，言之。 假令得传送青龙及王相之气，可为商贾。 得胜先大吉神将，皆宜田蚕。 亦以所欲为类神，上得凶者言。 所生得玄武，为亦遗。 余效此。 占诸市贾求利吉凶法第三十三 正日时，欲皆令今日之时辰上神及人年上神与所欲为市买物类，相生者吉。 又欲今日日辰，阴阳中有小吉、青龙，青龙所居神，与今日日辰上神相生者吉。 太岁上神不克人年上神，人年上神不制青龙者吉。 又欲令所往至之地，上有吉神将，有王相气，与人年上神不相贼，市估有利。 假令九月戊子日日映时，太冲加未，欲为估市，人年立己，太岁在寅，大吉为天一临於戊，戊寄位在己，己即人年立辰。 传送为青龙临子，此为有其物类。 其日辰与人年上神，及青龙所居神相生，大吉临人年，魁临太岁，不与人年神相贼，而北出传送下，大吉利。 虽先备二吉一凶，可用。 务令日辰人年上神，相生物类者，可用也。 式经云：审问所之之乡，东西南北四维，得与年相生，多王相之气者，即有福，估市有利。 不逢贼盗所居，见好所欲皆得。 但青龙居有气之神，而加有气之乡，即得财。 若青龙制人年，即无所得。 占诸欲畜集何者好法第三十四 正日时，各以其事类，在日辰阴阳及用传中有其物类，类又与人年上神相生者吉利，可为畜积也。 直用神始於无气，终於王相，即前利少后利多。 非此者，皆凶。 所言物类者，粟以木神，黍、小豆以火神，麦以金神，麻以土神，稻、大豆以水神，丝绵以太常，布帛以神后，皮革以白虎，田蚕以胜先。 假令七月甲子日鸡呜时，太一加丑，谋欲收麦，天罡加子，阴上神得传送，传送金神为麦类。 在用神阴阳中，人年立申，申上得神后，与传送相生为物类。 与人年上神相生也，是为可收也。 用起天罡，天罡气休老传终，皆得王相气，为后多利。 他效此。 占诸欲畜生类可得否法第三十五 正日时，视日辰上神，无魁罡、腾蛇、白虎，即吉，可畜收。 视其物类神，王相临有气之乡，为吉多利。 魁罡所加，不宜畜也。 假令魁罡加未，羊不可畜； 加亥，堵不可畜。 他效此。 占欲买车舟吉凶何如法第三十六 正日时，视日辰上神阴阳及用神传中有六合、太冲，与吉将并合，又与日相合者吉。

**Method 31: Determining the Auspiciousness of Cultivating Sericulture and the Five Grains**

Examine the **hourly stem-branch (正日时)**. If the **upper general (上神)** of the day’s branch contains abundant **Wang Xiang (王相) qi**, and the **general of the kind (类神)** aligns with it in **generating (相生)**, then it is **auspicious**.

If the **general of the Heavenly One (天一所居神)** also **generates (相生)** the same kind of general as the **upper general of the Great Year (太岁上神)**, then it is **greatly auspicious**.

If the **day’s branch (日辰)** and its **yin-yang (阴阳)** and **transmitted general (用传)** contain the kind’s general, then the crop will **bear fruit**.

If **Kui (魁), Gang (罡), Sheng She (剩蛇), Bai Hu (白虎), or prison-death qi (囚死之气)** are present in the day’s branch, then it is **inauspicious**.

The **kind’s general (物类者)** refers to:
- **Silkworms (蚕)** with **Sheng Qian (胜先)**
- **Grain (禾)** with **Gong Cao (功曹), Tai Chong (太冲)**
- **Millet (黍) and small beans (小豆)** with **Tian Yi (天一), Sheng Qian (胜先)**
- **Wheat (麦)** with **Chuan Song (传送), Cong Kui (从魁)**
- **Rice (稻) and large beans (大豆)** with **Deng Ming (登明), Shen Hou (神后)**
- **Hemp (麻)** with **Da Ji (大吉), Xiao Ji (小吉)**

For example, if one examines **silkworms (蚕)**, and the day’s branch contains **Sheng Qian (胜先)**, with **three transmitted Sheng Qian (胜先)**, all obtaining **auspicious generals (吉神将)**, and the **general of the Heavenly One (天一所居神)** and the **upper general of the Great Year (太岁上神)** both **generate (相生) Sheng Qian (胜先)**, then it is **greatly auspicious**.

For instance, if the **Great Year (太岁)** is in **Chen (辰)**, on a **fourth-month wu Chen (戊辰)** day at **midday (午)**, **Chuan Song (传送)** is present, and one inquires about the auspiciousness of **silkworms (蚕)**, then:
As **Sheng Qian (胜先)** is present in **Chen (辰)**, this signifies the kind’s general is present.
The **Great Year’s upper general (太岁上神)** naturally obtains **Sheng Qian (胜先)**, and the **general of the Azure Dragon (青龙神将)** will **generate (相生)** it.
**Tian Yi (天一)** is in **Da Ji (大吉)**, not **harming (相克)** **Sheng Qian (胜先)**, making it **greatly auspicious**.
All the **upper generals of the day’s branch (日辰上神)** contain **Wang Xiang (王相) qi**, with no calamities.
For all kinds of crops, apply the same method.

If the **kind’s general (物类神)** **harms (相贼)** the **upper general of the Great Year (太岁上神)**, the **general of the Heavenly One (天一所居神)** **harms (克)** the day’s branch, and there is no alignment of the kind’s general in **yin-yang (阴阳)**, then it is **greatly inauspicious and will fail**.

**Method 32: Determining the Auspiciousness of General Affairs, Trade, and Sericulture for the Current Year**

Examine the **day’s branch (日辰)** and the **upper general of the family head’s year (家长年上神将)**.

If one obtains **Chuan Song (传送)** and **Azure Dragon (青龙)**, along with **Wang Xiang (王相) qi**, then it is **auspicious for trade and commerce**.
If one obtains **Sheng Qian (胜先)** and **Da Ji (大吉) generals**, then it is **suitable for sericulture and farming**.
If the **kind’s general of the desired pursuit (所欲为类神)** is **auspicious**, yet the **upper general is malevolent**, then it is **inauspicious**.
If **Azure Dragon (青龙)** is in the **general’s position (所居)**, yet **herds and livestock (遗)** are present, then it is **inauspicious**.
Apply the same method elsewhere.

**Method 33: Determining the Auspiciousness of Market Trading and Seeking Profit**

Examine the **hourly stem-branch (正日时)**. If the **upper general of the day’s branch (今日之时辰上神)** and the **general of the person’s year (人年上神)** both **generate (相生)** the kind’s general of the desired **market purchase (市买)**, then it is **auspicious**.

If the **day’s branch (今日日辰)** contains **Xiao Ji (小吉)** or **Azure Dragon (青龙)**, and the **general of the Azure Dragon’s position (青龙所居神)** **generates (相生)** the **upper general of the day’s branch (今日日辰上神)**, then it is **auspicious**.

If the **upper general of the Great Year (太岁上神)** does not **harm (克)** the **general of the person’s year (人年上神)**, and the **general of the person’s year (人年上神)** does not **restrain (制)** the **Azure Dragon (青龙)**, then it is **auspicious**.

If the **desired location (所往至之地)** has **auspicious generals (吉神将)** with **Wang Xiang (王相) qi**, and the **general of the person’s year (人年上神)** does not **harm (相贼)** it, then the **market transaction (估市)** will be **profitable**.

For example, on a **ninth-month wu Zi (戊子)** day at **the hour of the day’s branch (日映时)**, with **Tai Chong (太冲)** added to **Wei (未)**, and one wishes to **engage in market transactions (估市)**, the **person’s year (人年)** is **Shen (申)**, and the **Great Year (太岁)** is in **Chen (辰)**.
**Da Ji (大吉)** is **Tian Yi (天一)** in **Wu (戊)**, with **Wu (戊)** borrowing the position of **Ji (己)**, and **Ji (己)** being the **day’s branch (日辰)**.
**Chuan Song (传送)** is **Azure Dragon (青龙)** in **Zi (子)**, signifying the presence of the kind’s general.
The **day’s branch (日辰)** and the **general of the person’s year (人年上神)**, along with the **general of the Azure Dragon’s position (青龙所居神)**, all **generate (相生)** one another.
**Da Ji (大吉)** is present in the **person’s year (人年)**, and **Kui (魁)** is present in the **Great Year (太岁)**, not **harming (相贼)** the **general of the person’s year (人年上神)**.
Since **Chuan Song (传送)** is in the **northern direction (北出)**, and **Da Ji (大吉)** is **profitable**, though there are **two auspicious and one inauspicious** factors, it is **still favorable**.
Ensure that the **upper generals of the day’s branch and the person’s year (日辰人年上神)** **generate (相生)** the kind’s general, then it is **suitable for use**.

The *Shi Jing (式经)* states:
*"Carefully inquire about the four directions—east, west, south, north—of the place you intend to go.
If the place **generates (相生)** the **year** and contains abundant **Wang Xiang (王相) qi**, then there will be **fortune (福)**, and the **market transaction (估市)** will be **profitable**.
If it does not encounter **harming or thieving generals (贼盗所居)**, and aligns with what is desired, then all will be obtained.
Only if the **Azure Dragon (青龙)** is in a **general’s position with qi (有气之神)**, and the place also has **qi (有气之乡)**, then **wealth (财)** will be obtained.
If the **Azure Dragon (青龙)** **restrains (制)** the **person’s year (人年)**, then nothing will be gained."*

**Method 34: Determining Which Livestock or Grain to Raise for Auspicious Harvest**

Examine the **hourly stem-branch (正日时)**. For each desired kind, if the **kind’s general (其事类)** is present in the **day’s branch (日辰)**, **yin-yang (阴阳)**, and **transmitted general (用传)**, and the **kind’s general (类)** also **generates (相生)** the **general of the person’s year (人年上神)**, then it is **auspicious and profitable**, and **suitable for raising**.

If the **transmitted general (用神)** begins at **no-qi (无气)** and ends at **Wang Xiang (王相)**, then **earlier factors are less profitable, while later ones are more profitable**.
If it does not follow this pattern, then it is **inauspicious**.

The **kind’s general (物类者)** refers to:
- **Millet (粟)** with **Wood general (木神)**
- **Millet (黍) and small beans (小豆)** with **Fire general (火神)**
- **Wheat (麦)** with **Metal general (金神)**
- **Hemp (麻)** with **Earth general (土神)**
- **Rice (稻) and large beans (大豆)** with **Water general (水神)**
- **Silk floss (丝绵)** with **Tai Chang (太常)**
- **Cloth and silk (布帛)** with **Shen Hou (神后)**
- **Leather and hides (皮革)** with **Bai Hu (白虎)**
- **Sericulture and grain (田蚕)** with **Sheng Qian (胜先)**

For example, on a **seventh-month jia Zi (甲子)** day at **the hour of the rooster’s crow (鸡呜时)**, with **Tian Yi (天一)** added to **Chou (丑)**, and one plans to **harvest wheat (收麦)**, **Tian Gang (天罡)** is added to **Zi (子)**.
The **yin upper general (阴上神)** obtains **Chuan Song (传送)**, and **Chuan Song (传送)**—the **Metal general (金神)**—is the kind’s general for **wheat (麦)**.
In the **yin-yang of the transmitted general (用神阴阳)**, the **person’s year (人年)** is in **Shen (申)**, and **Shen (申)** obtains **Shen Hou (神后)**, which **generates (相生)** **Chuan Song (传送)** as the kind’s general.
Since it **generates (相生)** the **general of the person’s year (人年上神)**, it is **suitable for harvest**.
The **transmitted general (用神)** begins with **Tian Gang (天罡)**, whose **qi is resting (休)** and **aging (老)** before the **transmission ends (传终)**.
All obtain **Wang Xiang (王相) qi**, making the **later factors more profitable**.
Apply the same method elsewhere.

**Method 35: Determining Whether Raising a Particular Kind of Livestock or Grain Will Succeed**

Examine the **hourly stem-branch (正日时)**. If the **day’s branch (日辰)** contains no **Kui (魁), Gang (罡), Teng She (腾蛇), or Bai Hu (白虎)**, then it is **auspicious and suitable for raising and harvesting**.

If the **kind’s general (物类神)** is **Wang Xiang (王相)** in a **qi-bearing direction (有气之乡)**, then it is **auspicious and highly profitable**.
If **Kui (魁)** or **Gang (罡)** are present, then it is **unfavorable for raising**.

For example, if **Kui (魁)** or **Gang (罡)** are added to **Wei (未)**, then **sheep (羊)** should not be raised.
If added to **Hai (亥)**, then **pigs (堵)** should not be raised.
Apply the same method elsewhere.

**Method 36: Determining the Auspiciousness of Purchasing Vehicles or Boats**

Examine the **hourly stem-branch (正日时)**. If the **day’s branch (日辰)** and its **yin-yang (阴阳)**, along with the **transmitted general (用传)**, contain **Liu He (六合)** or **Tai Chong (太冲)**, and these **align (并合)** with **auspicious generals (吉将)** and **harmonize (相合)** with the day, then it is **auspicious**.

By examining the **extremes (尤者)**, one discerns their manifestations:

**On Divination of Horses (吉凶法第三十七)**
If the **victorious general** aligns with **auspicious generals** in the **water direction**, it signifies **sickness**.
If it aligns with **Chou (丑)**, the horse will **love to run**.
If it aligns with **Xuan Wu (玄武)**, it will **escape and perish on its own**.
If it aligns with **Bai Hu (白虎)**, it will **die**.
If it aligns with **Sheng She (胜蛇)**, it will **cause alarm and ruin affairs**.
All other cases follow this pattern.

---

**On Divination of Oxen (善恶法第三十八)**
By **hourly stem-branch (正日时)**, assess with the **Great Auspicious (大吉)**.
If the **Great Auspicious** aligns with **wood**, it signifies **sickness**.
If it aligns with **fire**, it will **startle**, and the ox will be **sold**.
If it aligns with **metal**, it will **desire to be sold**.
If it aligns with **water**, it is a **field ox**.
If it aligns with **earth**, it is **livestock**.
If **Heaven and Earth are in darkness (天地昤)**, and the **auspicious star (用神)** aligns with **Tian Yi (天一)** in a **qi-bearing direction**, it will **enter state service**.
If it aligns with **Bai Hu (白虎)**, it will **die on its own**.
If it aligns with **Gou Chen (勾陈)**, it will **butt and harm people**.
If it aligns with **Sheng She (胜蛇)**, it will **frequently suffer alarm**.
If it aligns with **Xuan Wu (玄武)**, it will **be lost or abandoned**.
All other cases follow this pattern.
**Loss or abandonment** is attributed to the **Great Auspicious**, which is also the **Lake Star (湖神)**.
Another method attributes it to **Ji Xing (辑星)** below or **Tai Chong (太冲)**.

---

**On Divination of Sheep (可养得否法第三十九)**
By **hourly stem-branch (正日时)**, assess with the **Lesser Auspicious (小吉)**.
Adding **metal** indicates a desire to **keep it**.
Adding **wood** indicates a desire to **slaughter it**.
Adding **fire** allows it to be **kept**.
Adding **water** leads to **decline and waste**.
If it aligns with **auspicious generals** in a **qi-bearing direction**, it is **auspicious**.
If it aligns with **malevolent generals**, it is **unfavorable**.
Encountering **Bai Hu (白虎)** leads to **death**.
Adding **Yin (寅)** and **Xū (戌)** and meeting **Lang (狼)** also leads to **death**.
Adding **Chen (辰)** and entering the **grave** also leads to **death**.

---

**On Divination of Pigs (善恶法第四十)**
If **Deng Ming (登明)** is added to **Si (巳)** and **Wu (午)**, the pig will **escape**.
Adding a **water direction** makes it **filthy**.
Adding **metal or wood** allows it to be **kept**.
Adding **earth** leads to **sickness and death**.
Adding **Wang Xiang (王相)** directions, if **Tian Yi (天一)** and **Tai Yin (太阴)** align, it is for **sacrificial use**.
If it aligns with **malevolent generals** in **imprisonment or death directions**, it is **unfavorable**.
If **Deng Ming (登明)** aligns with **Bai Hu (白虎)**, it will **run away and be lost**.
To know **life or death**, observe the **qi**.
If there is **life qi**, it lives; if there is **death qi**, it dies.
If it aligns with **self-destruction** and **Sheng She (胜蛇)**, it will **flee in alarm**.
Adding **hourly stems, human years, or human graves** also leads to **death**.
For **lost or missing pigs**, if **Deng Ming (登明)** adds **You (酉)**, it is **unrecoverable**.
If **Wei (未)** is above and follows **Kui (魁)**, it is **unrecoverable**.
If **Si (巳)** is above and the **Lesser Auspicious (小吉)** aligns with **yin-yang controlling**, it can be **recovered**.

---

**On Divination of Dogs (可畜否法第四十一)**
By **hourly stem-branch (正日时)**, assess with the **He Kui (河魁)**.
**Zi (子)** can **catch mice**.
Adding **Mao (卯)** allows it to **run and hunt**.
Adding **Si (巳)** and **Wu (午)** makes it **good at barking**.
Adding **Wei (未)** makes it **good at fighting**.
Adding **Chen (辰)** leads to **self-destruction**.
Adding **Hai (亥)** means it will be **sold**.
Adding **Yin (寅)** makes it **mad and run wild**.
Adding **Xū (戌)** makes it **spray people**.
If it aligns with **Tai Yin (太阴)**, it is for **ritual use and sacrifice**.

---

**On Divination of Chickens (可畜否法第四十二)**
By **hourly stem-branch (正日时)**, assess with **Cong Kui (从魁)**.
Adding **Wei (未)** makes it **good for the household**.
Adding **metal or water** allows it to be **kept**.
Adding **Chou (丑)** leads to **self-destruction or being killed**.
Adding **Chen (辰)** makes it a **chick**.
Adding **Wei (未)** indicates it will be **used for sacrifice**.
If it aligns with **auspicious generals** in a **qi-bearing direction**, it is **auspicious**.
If it aligns with **malevolent generals** and also in **imprisonment or death directions**, it is **unfavorable**.
For example, if it aligns with **Sheng She (胜蛇)**, it will **be easily startled and act strangely**.
If it aligns with **Zhu Que (朱雀)**, it will **crow at inappropriate times**.
If it aligns with **Gou Chen (勾陈)**, a **hen will crow**.
If it aligns with **Xuan Wu (玄武)**, it will **flee and be lost**.
If it aligns with **Bai Hu (白虎)**, it will be **eaten by a weasel**.

---

**On Divination of Servants and Lowly Attendants (利主否法第四十三)**
By **hourly stem-branch (正日时)**, observe the **hourly stem’s yin-intestines (阴肠)**, the **auspicious star (用神)**, **Zhuan Zhong (传中)**, and **Cong Kui (从魁)**.
If it aligns with **auspicious generals** and has **Wang Xiang (王相)** or **restorative qi (休气)**, and harmonizes with the **hourly stem**, it is **suitable for the master**.
If the **auspicious star** is above and **malevolent** is below, it is **auspicious**, deeply beneficial for **loyalty and prosperity**.
If **Cong Kui (从魁)** is not in **yin-yang harmony** with the **hourly stem**, and the **auspicious star** and **Zhuan Zhong (传中)** align with **malevolent generals**, while also harming the **hourly stem**, and the **auspicious star** is below while **malevolent** is above, the servant will be **arrogant and flattering**, desiring to **harm the master**.

For example, in **August, on a Ren Zi (壬子) day during the fall**, if **Tian Gang (天罡)** adds **Wei (未)**, divining the **fortune of a servant**:
**Zhuan Song (传送)** is **Xuan Wu (玄武)** aligning with **Ren (壬)**, while **Cong Kui (从魁)** is **Tai Chang (太常)** aligning with **Zi (子)**. Since **Cong Kui (从魁)** harmonizes with **Ren (壬)** and **Wang Xiang (王相)**, and is within **yin-yang harmony**, while the **victorious general** is the **auspicious star** aligning with **You (酉)**, above harming below, at this time, **lowly attendants** will all be **favorable**.

For example, in **October, on a Yi Mao (乙卯) day at dusk**, if **Gong Cao (功曹)** adds **Xū (戌)**, above harming below, while **Cong Kui (从魁)** is **Liu He (六合)** aligning with **Si (巳)**, not within **yin-yang harmony**, and also harms the **Lesser Auspicious (小吉)** as the **auspicious star** aligning with **Mao (卯)**, below harming above, all indicate **arrogance and deceit**, desiring to **harm the master**.
It can still be **kept**.

---

**On Divination of Buying and Selling Goods and Livestock (知售否法第四十四)**
For **sellers**, the **hourly stem** should have **Wang Xiang (王相)**.
For **buyers**, the **hourly stem** should have **imprisonment or death**.
If the **animal’s corresponding star** is within **yin-yang harmony** and **Zhuan Zhong (传中)**, and harmonizes with the **hourly stem**, it is **auspicious**—**sellers** can **sell**, and **buyers** can **acquire**.
If the **animal’s corresponding star** is not within **yin-yang harmony** or **Zhuan Zhong (传中)**, and also harms the **hourly stem’s star**, both **buying and selling** will be **unsuccessful**.

For example, in **October, on a Gui Hai (癸亥) day during the fall**, if **Gong Cao (功曹)** adds **Wei (未)**, divining the **buying of an ox**:
The **Lesser Auspicious (小吉)** aligns with **water**, and the **yin star** obtains **Gong Cao (功曹)**.
The **victorious general** aligns with **Hai (亥)**, and the **yin star** obtains the **Great Auspicious (大吉)**.
Since it is within the **yin-intestines**, and does not harm the **hourly stem’s star**, both **seller and buyer** will be **satisfied**.

For example, on a **Geng Chen (庚辰) day**, divining the **selling of an ox**:
**Tai Chong (太冲)** aligns with **Geng (庚)**, and the **yin star** obtains **He Kui (河魁)**.
**Deng Ming (登明)** aligns with **Chen (辰)**, and the **yin star** obtains the **victorious general**.
The **Great Auspicious (大吉)** is not within **yin-yang harmony**, meaning **its kind is absent**.
The **hourly stem’s stars** all harm the **Great Auspicious (大吉)**, so both **buying and selling** will be **unsuccessful**.
For example, if the **hourly stem’s star** harms the **Great Auspicious (大吉)**, the **buyer will refuse**.
If the **hourly stem’s star** harms the **Great Auspicious (大吉)**, the **seller will refuse**.
If both **hourly stem’s stars** harm the **Great Auspicious (大吉)**, there will be **empty words**.
All other cases follow this pattern.

**On Divination of a Missing Person’s Whereabouts (吉凶法第四十五)**
*(Continued)*

At the **proper hour and day**, examine the **native star** of the person being inquired about and compare it to the **current day’s stem**. If they match, the person is present; if not, they are absent.

For example, if today is **Jia (甲)**, and one asks whether a person from **Wu (午)** is present: if the **Wu star** obtains **Chuansong (传送)**, which aligns with **Jia**, then—since **Jia** and **Shen (申)** are analogous—the person is present. If instead the **Wu star** obtains **Daji (大吉)** without **Jia-Chou (甲丑)**, they do not align, and the person is absent.

Another method: To determine whether a person is at home before visiting, observe the **star’s position** relative to the **day and hour**:
- If the **star follows** the **day and hour**, a woman in the household will wish to drink.
- If **Tian Gang (天罡)** governs the **day and hour**, there will be a dispute over money in the next household.
- If **Tai Yi (太一)** governs the **day and hour**, they will be crafting a small cart or wooden goods.
- Some say: *"Recently departed, soon to return."*
- If **Xiao Ji (小吉)** governs the **day and hour**, the person is in the woods or outside, not yet risen.

- If **Cong Kui (从魁)** governs the **day and hour**, they are in the next household.

- If **Gong Cao (功曹)** governs the **day and hour**, they are in an official’s home conversing with an elder guest.
- Some say: *"At home, working with wood, not leaving."*
- If **Tai Chong (太冲)** governs the **day and hour**, they are seen at the gate.

---
**On Divination for Petitioning, Memorials, and Meeting Noblemen (占欲上书奏记见贵人法第四十六)**

To petition, submit memorials, or meet noblemen, one must ensure that the **affair aligns with the celestial general’s nature**, that the **upper and lower stars harmonize**, and that the **governing star nurtures** the one it oversees. Only then will **Daji (大吉)** bring fortune; otherwise, misfortune follows.

For example, if petitioning to see the **King**, **Tian Yi (天一)** must govern **Metal, Fire, or Earth**, while the **hourly stem** aligns with **Metal, Fire, or Earth**.
To see a **Marquis**, use **Tai Chang (太常)**;
To see a **General**, use **Gou Chen (勾陈)**.

chunks.original_text: 见二千石，以青龙； 见令长，以朱雀。 效此非必在日辰阴阳中，宜视其事类神将，观其所喜善恶也。 所应喜，归母子。 占人奏文书劾事解否及何时来报法第四十七 日辰上得吉神将，有王相相生，即为吉。 功曹与吉将并，青龙与吉神并者，皆吉。 及直用神终见其子，有救者，为事解； 无救者，为不解。 假令望文章所在之乡在南方否？ 功曹、登明若青龙在北方下，为且至。 以功曹、登明临日辰，为至期。 法以传终救神，为至也。 占词讼吉凶事胜负法第四十八 以日上神为客主，上贼下，先者胜； 下贼上，后者胜。 胜者不可令先者年上下相贼，上下相贼，虽胜后必败殃。 日辰上下不相贼，两解不斗。 假令八月丁巳日时加巳，年立卯，功曹加之胜先，加丁日辰之阳神，并比和此，为两解者，准此。 若欲以长幼，则知胜负。 以今日长年辰为少壮也。 日胜辰，长者胜，谓日胜辰上神也。 辰胜日少者胜，谓辰胜日上神也。 以日辰上将言之，以知其胜负。 假令将得勾陈，见以斗争事相告也。 勾连将得白虎，忿争至死。 将得腾蛇，恐死有罪； 罪谓被笞也。 将得天空，所言非是，谓以论长短相告也。 将得朱雀，当狱讼； 谓争口舌事也。 将得玄武，胃辞而亡，亦主妄言。 假令讼者年立卯，传送临之，为年上下相贼，先者为客，后者为主。 占诸吏谋对计簿当见上官知喜怒法第四十九 正日时，视日上得吉神将，有王相及休气，与所欲见事类神将相生，即吉。 假令欲见王者，以天一； 诸侯，以太常；
